original: Charles Mumbere, the king of Rwenzururu, is entitled to these privileges because he suffers from hypertension and diabetes, it added. But prison authorities say an outsider will not be allowed into the prison to prepare his meals. The king was arrested last month after a security force raid on his palace in western Uganda's Kasese district. More than 80 people were killed in the clashes. The 64-year-old monarch denies any involvement in violence. He was arrested with more than 150 people, including royal guards. His lawyer, Caleb Alaka, told the BBC he will ensure that prison officials comply with the court order. Mr Alaka said he initially thought there was a royal cook among those arrested but they had all "perished" during the raid on the palace. The monarch would accept a cook appointed by prison authorities, he added. Officials also said there were no plugs in the cells to power fridges, local media reports. But Mr Alaka told the BBC the

original: Masai Graham won with the gag: "My dad suggested I register for a donor card, he's a man after my own heart." The festival's best jokes were selected by a panel of 10 judges before being put to 2,000 people, who voted for their favourite. Tim Vine, Stewart Francis and Zoe Lyon have previously won the competition, run by TV channel Dave. Graham, from West Bromwich, claimed the victory after making the shortlist in both 2014 and 2015. He said "It's an incredible honour to land Joke of the Fringe. Not bad for someone from West Brom!" Comedian Stuart Mitchell came second in the poll, with the joke: "Why is it old people say 'there's no place like home', yet when you put them in one..." Judges sat through an average of 60 different comedy performances and sifted through more than 3,600 minutes of material before selecting their favourite gags. In a bid to judge only the quality of the joke, the name of the comic or their show is not revealed during the voting process. Steve North, general manager of

original: Buckingham Palace announced on Friday evening that the Queen would not attend because she had gastroenteritis. Lord Lieutenant of West Glamorgan Byron Lewis took over the ceremonial role. The battalion's commanding officer said it would have been a first to have been presented leeks by the Queen. The cancellation by the Queen led to more sparse crowds watching the ceremony than had been anticipated. Speaking beforehand, commanding officer Rob Manuel said it had been "a bit of a surprise" when the announcement that the Queen would not be attending was made. However, he told BBC News: "We switched to plan B, and our thoughts and wishes are with her and we hope that she makes a speedy recovery. "The lord lieutenant has stepped into the breach. Today is going to run as per normal. "It would have certainly been a first for the queen to present leeks to 3rd Battalion, being a reserve battalion, especially for the chaps who have just come back from Afghanistan just before Christmas. "To have their leeks presented by the commander-in-chief is a really special day and really shows that the

original: Mr Joshua told his congregation on Sunday that he "saw" a woman winning. After Donald Trump convincingly won Tuesday's vote, visitors to the preacher's Facebook page noticed the prophecy had been removed. The wealthy pastor is known as "the prophet" to his many followers. He is one of Nigeria's best-known and influential evangelists - and is popular across Africa, with many top politicians among his flock. The US election prediction was broadcast on Mr Joshua's TV channel Emmanuel TV, which an individual uploaded to YouTube. A section of that "prophecy" was posted on the preacher's Facebook page but is no longer available. "Ten days ago I saw the president of America with a narrow win... What I frankly saw was a woman," it said. TB Joshua has been trending on Twitter across Nigeria, Ghana and South Africa as people shared memes poking fun at his prediction. People have also taken to a Facebook entry he posted on Wednesday to complain. Clive Mashiri from South Africa asked: "Why was the prophecy deleted? If this was uttered by the man of God, why remove it?" Though some have defended

original: Stephen Parnaby, Conservative leader of East Riding of Yorkshire Council, said the announcement was "great news for the town and the wider East Riding". The authority said it was spending about £100,000 on hosting the event. The organisers of last year's inaugural race said it brought £50m into the region's economy. The three-day event was launched by tourist body Welcome to Yorkshire after the county hosted the Tour de France Grand Depart in 2014. More than 1.2m people lined the 320-mile (515km) route. Mr Parnaby said last year's event had attracted thousands of spectators to the East Riding. "The council feels that the investment made by the authority, circa £100,000, to bring part of the race here is money well spent and will provide opportunities for local traders to capitalise on increased spending and help boost the East Riding economy," he said. Others in Beverley have also welcomed the race's arrival. Local amateur cyclist Ed Neilson said he hoped having the start of the race would encourage other cyclists to visit the town. original:
S4C gets most of its income from the licence fee and UK ministers have announced a major review of the BBC. Monmouth MP David Davies has endorsed this initiative, suggesting the review will ensure a more transparent and accountable broadcasting service. 

The BBC currently operates under a Royal Charter, which is up for renewal every 10 years. This review will assess its public purposes, funding, and governance structure. Critics have raised concerns about the potential for political interference, however, Davies argued that the review will only enhance the BBC’s ability to deliver high-quality content to its viewers.

S4C, the Welsh-language public-service television channel, will also be impacted by this review. It heavily relies on the licence fee, receiving around 90% of its income from this source. The review will scrutinise the efficiency and effectiveness of this funding model, potentially impacting S4C's future operation. The results of the review will be awaited with interest by both viewers and broadcasters.

original: PC Frances Tilley admitted she had "destroyed her career" after evading payment for a journey between Bristol Temple Meads station and Castle Cary in Somerset last June. A disciplinary hearing at Northamptonshire Police headquarters heard she was less than two years into her job and was still on probation. She was dismissed for gross misconduct. The hearing at Wootton Hall heard Tilley travelled from Northampton to Castle Cary on 22 June last year. The officer, described as "diligent, professional and committed", was travelling with friends and did not buy a ticket for the final leg of her journey. Force solicitor Elizabeth Briggs said: "She travelled from Bristol to Westbury and onto Castle Cary. At that stage, she did not have a valid ticket to travel. "There were opportunities for her to purchase a ticket. "She said it was her intention to not pay a rail fare for that part of the journey." original: The charity wants 10% of the 4.8 million Syrians displaced by civil war to be resettled by the end of the year. Ahead of UN talks in Geneva on the crisis, it highlighted figures showing only 1.4% had been helped so far. Oxfam said UK plans to resettle 20,000 Syrians by 2020 were "not good enough", but Britain says it is also focused on providing aid to people in the region. The UK's pledge of Â£2.3bn to help people affected by the humanitarian crisis caused by the civil war in Syria makes it the second largest bilateral donor in the world after the US. Oxfam says while Britain has been generous in providing financial aid for those displaced by Syria's civil war, it "can and should do more". It argues that countries with strong economies and developed infrastructures need to shoulder a greater responsibility towards refugees than nations such as Lebanon and Jordan, where thousands of Syrians are now based. The Geneva conference should, the UK-based charity added, result in "urgent solutions, offering people safe and legal routes to a welcome" in other countries.

With a £2.3bn pledge to aid those affected by Syria's civil war, the UK is the world's second largest bilateral donor after the US. Oxfam acknowledges the UK's financial generosity but insists it "can and should do more." It contends that wealthy countries with advanced infrastructures must bear more responsibility for refugees than Lebanon and Jordan, which host thousands of Syrians. The UK-based charity hopes the Geneva conference will lead to "urgent solutions, providing safe and legal routes for refugees to be welcomed" elsewhere.

Mark Footitt took 3-52 as the visitors lost five wickets before lunch while Sam Curran dismissed England opener Haseeb Hameed Mark Footitt put on a stellar performance, taking 3-52 as the visitors lost five wickets before lunch, creating a palpable tension on the field. Severely felt was the absence of England opener Haseeb Hameed, dismissed by Sam Curran in an unexpected twist. 

Hameed's exit came as a blow to the visitors, reflecting in their performance and the resulting score. Curran's brilliant strategy and execution were hailed as the turning point of the game. His dismissal of Hameed set the stage for Footitt to demonstrate his exceptional bowling skills, leading to the loss of five wickets, a testament to the home team's prowess.

The match, well into its challenging phase, was characterized by strategic play and surprising upsets. High anticipation surrounds the post-lunch session, with all eyes on the visitors' batting line-up and whether they can recover from the morning setback.

original: As with last year's parade, only the Orangemen and their 13 notified bands can march past St Patrick's Church on Donegall Street in north Belfast. They must do so to the sound of a single drum beat. This year all music must stop 43 metres away from the church so there is no music within earshot of it. A planned residents' protest has also been restricted to a maximum of 50 people at two locations. The Orange Order has said it is appalled by the determination. "The commission is now simply a mouthpiece for republican propaganda, allowing them to dictate the terms of when, how and where loyal order parades are held," it said. "The invented new criteria of banning music within 'earshot' of a place of worship not in use, is as mischievous as it is absurd, and clearly put in place to further censor Protestant heritage on the supposed

They called the new rule banning music within 'earshot' of an unused place of worship both mischievous and absurd, aimed at censoring Protestant heritage."

original: In a statement, it said Foreign Affairs Secretary Perfecto Yasay would raise the issue at a major two-day Asia-Europe summit starting on Friday, attended by China's Premier Li Keqiang. A UN-backed tribunal ruled on Tuesday that there was no legal basis to China's claims in the South China Sea. China has vowed to ignore the ruling. It says the panel has no jurisdiction and its activities in the region will not be affected. The Asia-Europe Meeting Summit (Asem) in Ulaanbaatar in Mongolia on Friday and Saturday will be the first major multilateral diplomatic gathering since the 12 July ruling over the South China Sea. The summit will see 53 leaders from Asia and Europe attending, including from countries such as Vietnam and Malaysia which also claim territory in the region. It will also be the first meeting in which the new Philippine government of President Rodrigo Duterte will be represented on the world stage. The Department of Foreign Affairs said Mr Yasay,

original:
The party's election manifesto said a funding floor would only be provided after a referendum was called. The St David's Day Agreement had said the vote should be held before such a move could be made. The seeming inconsistency has sparked a fierce debate among political parties and citizens alike, questioning the party's commitment to financial transparency and accountability.

Critics suggest that the move is a strategic ploy for the party to gain a political advantage, while supporters argue that it is a necessary step toward ensuring the smooth allocation of resources. The decision has also raised questions about the party's adherence to the St David's Day Agreement, which many view as a cornerstone of political practice and a pillar of democratic engagement. 

The party, in response to the concerns raised, maintains its stance that this move is in line with its commitment to strengthen democracy and promote fairer distribution of resources. Despite the controversy, the party stands firm on its decision, stating that the referendum is not an obstacle, but a necessary democratic process.

However, the St David's Day Agreement mandated that the vote should precede such funding decisions. This apparent contradiction has ignited intense debate among politicians and the public, casting doubt on the party's dedication to financial transparency and accountability.

original: The European Challenge Tour event will be part of a big week in the season with both the US PGA Championship and Women's British Open also taking place. Tournament ambassador Hoey expects several European Tour winners to be in the Galgorm field. They are set to come up against several up and coming stars of the future. "The NI Open will attract an even stronger field than in previous years," says five-time European Tour winner Hoey. "Especially because it has such a good place on the schedule." Hoey's fellow Irish European Tour winners Peter Lawrie, Damien McGrane and Simon Thornton are all expected to compete while Walker Cup hero from 2015, Ardglass man Cormac Sharvin, is also likely to tee up. Charles Mumbere, the king of Rwenzururu, is entitled to these privileges because he suffers from hypertension and diabetes, it added. The royal family has requested special medical care and dietary accommodations for the ailing king, citing his dual conditions that require meticulous attention. 

In response to this request, the government has confirmed that they will ensure the necessary measures are taken to guarantee the king's health. An official statement released yesterday stated, "The government is committed to providing the best possible care for King Mumbere. We recognize his significant role in our country's history and his current state of health demands special attention."

King Mumbere has been battling hypertension and diabetes for many years now. His condition has raised concerns among the kingdom's subjects, who regard him as a significant symbol of unity and cultural heritage. original: The party's 54 sitting MPs are expected to be endorsed as candidates. A decision will also be made about the fate of Natalie McGarry and Michelle Thomson, who were elected as SNP MPs but now sit as independent members. Labour's executive is also expected to decide candidate selection, while some challengers have come forward for the Conservatives and Lib Dems already. The UK goes to the polls on 8 June after Prime Minister Theresa May announced plans for a snap election, subsequently endorsed by MPs by 552 votes to 13. Ms McGarry and Ms Thomson were the only two Scottish MPs to vote against the election, with SNP members abstaining. If they do not return, the SNP will need to find five candidates, including three for the seats the party did not win in 2015. A number of party activists have already announced their intention to bid for the SNP ticket in the Glasgow East and Edinburgh West seats formerly occupied by the two women. On Friday, the UK Labour party issued a call for prospective for parliamentary candidates over Twitter, inviting party members to apply with a deadline

Ben Purdy, 18, was shot in the head in Bermondsey after confronting his girlfriend's ex about "threatening" messages sent after their breakup. 

Ben Purdy, 18, was shot in the head in Bermondsey after confronting his girlfriend's ex about "threatening" messages sent after their break-up. The tragic incident, which took place around 11 PM on Sunday, has left the community in shock and mourning. 

Purdy, known for his bravery and sense of justice, had reportedly approached the man in an attempt to quell the tension that had been building since the break-up. Unfortunately, the confrontation escalated to a deadly turn, resulting in the fatal shooting of the young man. 

Local authorities are investigating the case rigorously, while the community rallies together in memory of Purdy. The alleged shooter, now identified as the ex-boyfriend, is in police custody awaiting trial. This tragic event highlights the escalating issue of gun violence and the urgent need for a solution. As the investigation unfolds, the community holds its breath, hoping for justice for Ben Purdy.

original: The last print edition will be on 31 December, reflecting the trend for newspapers and magazines to move online as traditional advertising declines. Newsweek merged with the internet news group the Daily Beast two years ago. The Daily Beast's founder, Tina Brown, said its site now had more than 15 million unique visitors a month, a 70% increase on last year. She said in a statement: "Exiting print is an extremely difficult moment for all of us who love the romance of print and the unique weekly camaraderie of those hectic hours before the close on Friday night. By Ben ThompsonBusiness reporter, New York In 1933, Newsweek hit the news stands - a weekly magazine covering global events. But much like the world it's reported on over the last 80 years, much has changed in the publishing world too. Not least how consumers get their news. The number of Newsweek subscribers has slumped from more than 3 million at its peak to 1.5 million today. Couple that with falling advertising revenues for traditional print media and it's led Newsweek to ditch its print edition altogether. Newsweek Global, the digital only version, will be available via

Two years ago, Newsweek combined with the online news outlet The Daily Beast. Tina Brown, founder of The Daily Beast, reported their website now attracts over 15 million unique monthly visitors, up 70% from last year. She remarked, "Leaving print is a tough moment for those of us who cherish the romance of print and the unique weekly rush before Friday night's deadline." By Ben Thompson, Business Reporter, New York. Newsweek began in 1933 as a weekly magazine covering global affairs, but like the world it reports on, the publishing landscape has drastically changed over 80 years. original: It means instead of people owning cars and bikes, one version of the future is we all hire transport to get around. This week we got another example of that in the capital when oBike launched. It is a company backed by considerable venture capital and it's putting hundreds of hire bikes on London's streets. The company aims to have thousands in the capital by the end of the summer, after already operating huge schemes in South East Asia. The big difference compared to the existing cycle hire scheme is the bikes have no docking stations. A locking rear brake means they can be left anywhere. Users access them via an app and you can find them as they have a GPS locator. There is a one-off Â£49 refundable deposit to be paid and then 50p per half-hour. More companies are set to follow. oBike says it is aiming to work in conjunction with the existing scheme and it

They spend an average of £581 a year on music festivals, often opting for VIP passes or upgraded camping options. Predominantly between the ages of 18 and 34, these individuals represent a significant portion of the UK's festival-going population. 

This demographic, known for its love of live music and social experiences, is consistently boosting the economy through its festival expenditures. From Glastonbury to Reading and Leeds, festivals have become a significant summer pastime, attracting visitors from all across the globe. 

The rise in deluxe camping options and VIP passes indicates a growing desire for more comfortable and exclusive festival experiences. This demand has led to increased diversity within festival offerings, with many events now featuring gourmet food stalls, luxury accommodations, and high-end amenities. 

While some argue that these changes detract from the traditional, more rugged festival experience, others appreciate the chance to enjoy the music and atmosphere in relative comfort. Either way, the festival industry continues to thrive and evolve, fueled largely by this

original:
The child, who was under 13, needed medical treatment following the attack by Ajay Jetha last year. A probation report three months earlier had identified Jetha as a potential risk to minors but lamentably, authorities failed to act. 

The attack, which occurred in Leicester, sparked public outrage and demands for a review of the probation system. It was revealed that Jetha, a 35-year-old man with a history of violent behavior, was not properly monitored after the damning report.

Prosecutors say the victim was subjected to a terrifying ordeal that has left her traumatized. The attack became a watershed moment, prompting serious questions about the effectiveness of the probation service in predicting and preventing such horrifying incidents. 

Jetha has since been sentenced to 10 years in prison. Meanwhile, the victim's family, with the support of their local community, is calling for a complete overhaul of the probation system to ensure no other child falls through the cracks.

original:
Sales at the company rose to €34.2bn (£28.8bn) in the year to 2021, marking its strongest annual performance in a decade, despite the ongoing global pandemic. This impressive surge in revenue, up by 27% from €26.9bn (£22.6bn) in 2020, underlines the company's resilience in a challenging business environment. The growth was driven largely by robust demand for the company's innovative product line and its successful expansion into new international markets. 

While many businesses have struggled due to Covid-19 restrictions, the company pivoted effectively, capitalising on the surge in online shopping and remote work. The firm also managed to strengthen its supply chain, thereby ensuring uninterrupted service to its global customer base.

Moving into 2022, the company plans to continue its investment in research and development, aiming to launch new products and further expand its global footprint. The company's strong financial performance sends a positive signal to investors about its capability

original: The 10 trees have been nominated by members of the public for the competition run by the Woodland Trust charity. A public vote will decide the winner, which will then compete against trees from across the Continent for the title of European Tree of the Year. The online voting ends on 9 October. The Woodland Trust said a panel of experts whittled down 200 public nominations based on the nominees' story, The winning tree will benefit from a care grant of Â£1,000 and any tree receiving over 1,000 votes will receive a grant of Â£500. Nominations include the "Sycamore Gap" tree near Hadrian's Wall in Northumberland. It appeared alongside Kevin Costner in the 1991 film Robin Hood Prince of Thieves. Another finalist is a tree in Sheffield which is threatened with felling as part of the city's street improvement scheme. variant_1: The Woodland Trust charity's competition features 10 trees nominated by the public. The winner will be chosen by a public vote and then compete against other European trees for the title of European Tree of the Year. Online voting closes on 9 October. A panel of experts narrowed down 200 nominations based on their stories. The winning tree receives a £1,000 care grant, and any tree with over 1,000 votes gets a £500 grant. Among the nominees is the "Sycamore Gap" tree near Hadrian's Wall, featured in the 1991 film Robin Hood Prince of Thieves. Another finalist is a Sheffield tree threatened by a street improvement scheme. Paul Selby, a local campaigner who nominated it, said making the shortlist highlights its national significance.

The winning tree will get a £1,000 care grant, and trees with over 1,000 votes receive £500. Nominations include the "Sycamore Gap" tree near Hadrian's Wall, seen in the 1991 film Robin Hood Prince of Thieves. original: Until now, Google Assistant had only been available on the firm's own Pixel phones. The service, like Siri on iPhones, allows users to interact with apps and ask questions. LG was one of the first smartphone makers to reveal it would feature the assistant on its new device, the G6. Google's update will starting rolling out this week to users with Android 6.0 Marshmallow or 7.0 Nougat installed. "With this update, hundreds of millions of Android users will now be able to try out the Google Assistant," said Gummi Hafsteinsson, product lead for Google Assistant, in a blog post. But other virtual assistants are out there. At the Mobile World Congress tech show in Barcelona, Lenovo Moto revealed that Amazon's Alexa assistant would be coming to the Moto Z phone. original: It means instead of people owning cars and bikes, one version of the future is we all hire transport to get around. This week we got another glimpse into this potential future with Uber announcing its expansion into the e-bike rental industry. The ride-hailing giant has acquired Jump, a startup that provides dockless electric bikes allowing users to pick up and drop off bikes anywhere in the city. This move is a strategic pivot for Uber, a company traditionally associated with private car services, showcasing their willingness to adapt to the changing landscape of urban transportation. As we move towards a more sustainable and interconnected world, shared modes of transport, including bike sharing systems like Jump, are increasingly viewed as a viable alternative to private vehicle ownership. While there are still kinks to iron out, such as regulation and infrastructure, this acquisition indicates we're one step closer to a future where personal vehicle ownership may not be the norm.
variant_1: Instead of individuals owning cars and bikes, one possible future is that we all rent transportation to get around. This week, Uber gave us another look at this potential future by announcing its move into the e-bike rental market. The ride-hailing giant has purchased Jump, a startup offering dockless electric bikes that users can pick up and drop off anywhere in the city. This acquisition marks a strategic shift for Uber, a company traditionally linked to private car services, demonstrating their readiness to adapt to the evolving urban transportation scene. As we progress toward a more sustainable and connected world, shared transportation options like bike-sharing systems such as Jump are increasingly seen as practical alternatives to private vehicle ownership. Despite challenges like regulations and infrastructure that still need resolving, this acquisition suggests we are closer to a future where owning a personal vehicle may no longer be standard.

original: OUP analysed more than 120,421 short stories by children aged between five and 13 years old, submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. According to the OUP, new technology is increasingly at the centre of the children's lives but how they are writing about it is changing fast. Words including email, mobile and Facebook are in decline, it said. They are being replaced by the likes of Instagram, Snapchat and emoji. And the word television has now been superseded by phone. The report also notes a sudden new arrival in children's sentences. The use of the hashtag symbol # to add an extra meaning or comment at the end of a sentence has become commonplace. #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. variant_1: OUP examined over 120,421 short stories written by children aged 5 to 13, submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. Their analysis shows that while new technology plays an ever-greater role in kids' lives, the way they write about it is evolving rapidly. Terms like email, mobile, and Facebook are declining in use, replaced by Instagram, Snapchat, and emoji. Additionally, the word television has been overtaken by phone. The report also highlights the rise of the hashtag (#) symbol being used at the end of sentences to add meaning or commentary, such as #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. Vineeta Gupta of Oxford University Press stated this shift in 2015 marks a notable change in how children use hashtags, extending their function beyond mere prefixes or search tags.
variant_2: Oxford University Press analyzed more than 120,421 short stories from children aged five to 13 submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. They found that new technology is becoming central to children's lives, but the language they use to describe it is changing rapidly. Words like email, mobile, and Facebook are falling out of favor and being replaced by Instagram, Snapchat, and emojis. Television has also been replaced by phone in their vocabulary. The report notes the hashtag symbol (#) has become common at the end of sentences to add extra meaning or commentary, exemplified by #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. Vineeta Gupta from Oxford University Press remarked that 2015 saw a significant shift in hashtag usage, where children now use it beyond just a prefix or search term.

original: The Black Caps, having been set a world record 504 to win, resumed on 142-3 and their challenge quickly folded. Brendon McCullum hit a run-a-ball 80 but the Kiwis were all out for 295. Spinner Nathan Lyon took 3-63 in the second innings, while Mitchell Starc, Josh Hazlewood and Mitchell Marsh claimed two wickets apiece. Australia's first innings 556-4 declared set them up for the victory and opener David Warner was named man of the match for his scores of 163 and 116. "I thought the first morning really set the tone for us with Joe Burns and Davy Warner batting so well," Australia captain Steve Smith said. "I thought the top order set the test match up for us. The partnerships that we had in that top three were crucial to our success." The second Test begins in Perth on Friday and the series concludes with the inaugural day-night Test in Adelaide. New Zealand now face a tough task

original:
Yorkshire batsman Joe Root has been named as new Test captain after Alastair Cook resigned after more than four years in charge. "We feel that Joe Root is the perfect choice to take over the reins from Alastair Cook," said the England Cricket Board (ECB) in a statement. Yorkshire batsman Joe Root has been named as the new Test captain after Alastair Cook resigned after more than four years in charge. Cook's resignation marked the end of an era and the beginning of Root's leadership. 

Root, 30, is considered one of the best batsmen in the world, with a Test average of close to 50. His appointment reflects his consistent performance and the respect he commands within the squad. "We are confident that he will lead the team to new heights," the ECB statement added. Root will be the 80th man to lead England in a Test match when he takes charge for the first time this summer. His first series in charge will be against South Africa at home. Root's vice-captain will be Ben Stokes.

Root, aged 30, is regarded as one of the world's top batsmen, boasting a near 50 Test average. His consistent excellence and the respect he holds in the team underpin his selection. The ECB expressed confidence in his ability to elevate the team. Root will become England's 80th Test captain when he leads the team for the first time this summer, beginning with a home series against South Africa. Ben Stokes has been named as his deputy.

original: Remus Hamza, 40, is alleged to have attacked the 20-year-old near Cardiff University as she walked home alone after a night out with friends on 20 September. The prosecution at Newport Crown Court has alleged she was so drunk she could not have consented to sex. The defendant, who is Romanian and lives in Cardiff, denies rape. The court heard the woman lost her friends during her night out and started to walk home along Greyfriars Road, under an underpass by City Hall and then along Museum Avenue at about 02:00 GMT. It was here she was approached by the defendant and the alleged rape happened behind a bush. Claire Pickthall, prosecuting, told the jury the victim was "so drunk she can't remember the incident happening. She can't even remember him having sex with her". original:
The walk-in service is aimed at reducing doctor appointments and to help reduce the over-use of antibiotics, NHS England said. It is hoped that the new approach will provide a more efficient and effective means for patients seeking treatment for minor ailments, potentially cutting down waiting times and easing the pressure on general practices.

The service is a strategic step in implementing the overarching goal of NHS England to manage antibiotic resistance, a growing health concern worldwide. Overuse of antibiotics has been linked to the emergence of resistant bacterial strains, posing a significant global health risk.

The walk-in service will be based in pharmacies across England, with trained practitioners providing on-the-spot advice and treatment without the requirement of an appointment. The list of ailments to be covered under the service includes sore throats, colds, and minor infections.

NHS England believes that this initiative will not only reduce the strain on GP surgeries and hospitals but also help in educating the public about the perils of overusing antibiotics. By integrating pharmacies more deeply into the healthcare

The Spy Who Came In From The Cold, set at the height of the Cold War, is being adapted by the Oscar-winning writer of The Imitation Game, Graham Moore. The espionage thriller, originally a novel by John le Carré, will be making its transition into a gripping television drama. Moore, known for his ability to masterfully craft complex narratives, is set to bring a fresh perspective to the classic Cold War story.

The novel's protagonist, Alec Leamas, a hardworking British agent who is in the throes of the East-West conflict in Berlin, will be the focal point of this adaptation. The story's timeless themes of loyalty, betrayal, and human integrity are set to be explored in depth, promising a thrilling experience for viewers.

This adaptation is expected to bring a new generation of viewers closer to le Carré’s work, while also pleasing long-time fans with its faithful rendition of the novel’s atmospheric tension and intricate plot. The production date is yet to be announced,

The Â£1m project on land near Sanquhar was funded by the Duke of Buccleuch. It will be launched on Sunday with a performance by a cast of 30 dancers and musicians. The Crawick Artland Trust, which manages the site, has said it hopes to attract international visitors and boost business in Sanquhar, Kelloholm and Kirkconnel. He said: "Through conversations with Charles Jencks and with the Duke of Buccleuch and the local community, it is clear to me that my job is to present something which is interesting to look at in itself but allows other people to see the potential of the site for future events." original: The changes would allow Japanese troops to fight abroad for the first time since World War Two. The legislation has already been passed by Japan's lower house, signalling a significant shift from Japan's post-war pacifism and marking a milestone in its military normalization. The bill, if approved by the upper house, would extend Japan's military options by ending a ban on exercising collective self-defense, or aiding an ally under attack. While supporters argue that it is crucial for Japan to strengthen its role in global security amid growing regional threats, the move has triggered widespread protests from citizens and constitutional scholars who contend it violates Japan's constitution and could potentially embroil the country in U.S.-led conflicts around the globe. This legislation is a reflection of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's push for Japan to take on a more assertive military posture, a stance that has raised eyebrows within the international community.
variant_1: The amendments would permit Japanese forces to engage in combat overseas for the first time since World War II. The legislation has already passed Japan's lower house, marking a notable departure from its post-war pacifist stance and a key step toward normalizing its military capabilities. If the upper house approves the bill, it would broaden Japan's defense options by lifting the ban on collective self-defense, allowing aid to allies under attack. Proponents claim this is essential for Japan to bolster its role in global security amid rising regional threats, but the move has sparked widespread protests from citizens and constitutional experts who argue it breaches Japan's constitution and risks involving the nation in U.S.-led international conflicts. This legislation exemplifies Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's effort to adopt a more assertive military policy, a position that has drawn international attention.

original: The 31-year-old tweeted she was turned away from a black cab and told to "find an immigrant" to give her a ride. The alleged altercation comes after she apologised "on behalf of my country" over squalid conditions at the Jungle camp in Calais. The Licensed Taxi Drivers' Association said it condemned abusive behaviour. The singer wrote on Twitter: "Just tried to get in a black cab with my kids. The driver looked at me and said 'find an immigrant to drive you you stupid tart'." She went on to add: "Having lived a life of privilege, that interaction has given me a tiny glimpse of what it feels like to be discriminated against." Her claims have been questioned by some. One Twitter user said it "definitely didn't happen", while another asked her to reveal the taxi's registration plate. She wrote they were "victim shaming" her and replied: "I had both my hands full with children, couldn't get to my phone fast enough." The association, which

The Licensed Taxi Drivers' Association condemned the abusive behavior. On Twitter, the singer wrote: "I just tried to get into a black cab with my kids. Taibu, 32, played 28 Test matches and 150 one-day internationals for Zimbabwe prior to retiring in 2012. "When he explained who he was, it was like meeting a legend in person," said young fan, Tinashe Moyo, who had never had the chance to see the wicketkeeper-batsman play in his prime. 

In his ten-year career, Taibu was renowned for his technical proficiency, agility behind the stumps, and captaincy. His retirement shocked many, as he was still at the peak of his prowess, but he cited personal and family reasons for his decision.

Since hanging up his cricket pads, Taibu has devoted his time to promoting and developing the sport at grassroots level in African communities. Many young athletes have benefited from his mentorship and training, and his dedication to giving back to the sport has been lauded by sporting and community figures alike.

Taibu's career might have ended on the pitch, but his

The were 37 crimes recorded in Cromer over the weekend - including the rape of a teenager - with residents linking them to a group of travellers. The weekend saw an alarming total of 37 crimes recorded in Cromer, including a horrifying incident of a teenage girl being raped. Local residents believe the crimes are linked to a group of travellers who moved into the area recently.

The spate of incidents began on Friday night, with reports of thefts, disturbances, and disorderly behaviour. But it was the sexual assault on the teenager that has left the community in shock and fear. Local authorities are treating the incident with utmost severity and have launched a full-scale investigation.

The police are conducting regular patrols and checks in the area to ensure residents' safety. Authorities have also called for calm and urged residents not to take matters into their own hands, assuring them that every possible step is being taken to bring the culprits to justice.

Residents have been asked to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activities to the police. The incidents have sparked a debate about the need for better security measures in the seaside town.

original: A website polled users as to which country he should tour next, with no restrictions on the nations that could be voted on. There are now almost half a million votes to send the singer to the secretive communist nation. The contest, which ends at 0600 on 7 July, saw North Korea move from 24th to 1st place in less than two days. Many of the votes are thought to originate from imageboard website 4chan, which has built a reputation for triggering online viral campaigns. The voting site is not endorsed by Mr Bieber's record label. Given the fact that almost all citizens of North Korea are denied internet access and there are restrictive controls over all media, it is unlikely that any of the votes have actually come from within the country. But he fancied his video game skills and entered Nissan's GT Academy competition while on a gap year. After beating 90,000 other gamers from across the globe, the prodigious talent, Joe Smith, stepped into the spotlight. 

Many scoffed at the idea of a video gamer transitioning into a professional race car driver, but Smith proved them wrong. The 23-year-old demonstrated his skill set was not confined to virtual competitions. His tenacity, determination, and an uncanny knack for strategic gameplay led him to outpace his competitors and clinch the championship. 

Smith's incredible journey from a casual gamer to a professional racer has not only redefined traditional pathways into motorsports but also validated the place of e-sports in mainstream competition. His victory at the GT Academy has set a precedent, proving that passion, dedication, and skill can overcome traditional barriers. This triumph signifies a victory for all e-sports enthusiasts and a game-changing moment for the world of competitive racing.

original: These beautiful pictures are the first ever taken of a wild lioness nursing a cub from a different species - an extremely rare event. The pair were spotted by Joop Van Der Linde, a guest at Ndutu Safari Lodge in Tanzania's Ngorongoro Conservation Area. The scene is the Serengeti; the attentive mother, five-year-old Nosikitok. The lioness has a GPS collar fitted by Kope Lion, a conservation NGO, and three young cubs of her own - born around the 27-28 June. Dr Luke Hunter, President and Chief Conservation Officer for Panthera, a global wild cat conservation organisation which supports Kope Lion, told the BBC the incident was "truly unique". "It's not something that I'm aware has ever happened before between large cats like this," he said. "We know there are cases where lionesses will adopt other lion cubs... But this is unprecedented. "I know of no other case - between any large cat, for that matter - where the
variant_1: These stunning photos are the first known images of a wild lioness nursing a cub from another species, a highly unusual occurrence. The pair was observed by Joop Van Der Linde, a visitor at Ndutu Safari Lodge in Tanzania's Ngorongoro Conservation Area. The setting is the Serengeti, featuring the caring mother, five-year-old Nosikitok. The lioness wears a GPS collar placed by Kope Lion, a conservation NGO, and has three cubs of her own born around June 27-28. Dr. Luke Hunter, President and Chief Conservation Officer of Panthera, a global wild cat conservation group supporting Kope Lion, told the BBC the event was "truly unique." "To my knowledge, this has never been documented before among large cats," he said. "While lionesses sometimes adopt other lion cubs, this situation is unprecedented. I know of no similar case among any large cat species."

original:
The latest Markit Report on Jobs for Scotland found sharp rises in permanent and temporary job placements in April. Growth in temporary staff demand was also at its highest rate since December 2018, providing positive signals about the Scottish job market. 

The report indicates an accelerated increase in permanent staff appointments, and recruiters signaled a strong upturn in short-term roles. This surge is particularly notable after the economic slowdown caused by the pandemic. The demand for workers is increasing in various sectors, with IT & Computing leading the way in permanent staff demand, whereas Nursing/Medical/Care topped the demand for temporary staff.

Moreover, the availability of candidates for permanent roles deteriorated at a steep and accelerated rate, leading to a surge in starting salaries. Meanwhile, temp wages also grew at a faster pace. 

This data suggests that Scotland's job market is bouncing back robustly, with increasing demand for both permanent and temporary staff and growing wages, bringing a much-needed boost to the Scottish economy.

original: An official has told an assembly committee that Cardiff Aviation, which has leased a hangar at St Athan from the administration since 2012, has not paid rent for the last three years. The Vale of Glamorgan-based maintenance and repair firm, co-owned by Iron Maiden singer Bruce Dickinson, faces financial difficulties since 2019, leading to delayed rent payments. The official disclosed that the outstanding rent totals an estimated £500,000. The revelation has sparked a significant concern among the assembly members over the administration's measures to ensure the collection of due payments. The company's failure to pay rent has put additional financial pressure on St Athan, already struggling due to the economic impact of the pandemic. Assembly members are now urging the administration to take immediate action to recoup the lost funds. Cardiff Aviation is yet to comment on the matter. This situation has highlighted the need for stricter enforcement of lease agreements to protect public finances.

original: Transport for London (TfL) is to consult on plans to demand a new English language test, a map-reading assessment, a fixed landline and the chance to book seven days in advance. Uber said: "If adopted these [rules] would mean an end to the Uber people know and love." Black cab drivers have argued regulations need to be tightened. There has been growing pressure on city legislators, most recently when cab drivers protested outside City Hall. The Uber app connects customers and nearby drivers using GPS technology and gives an estimate of the fare. It generally charges lower fares than traditional firms and drivers rely on technology for navigation. Transactions are cashless using pre-registered bank details. TfL says the consultation seeks to "raise standards across the industry" following an "exponential" growth in the private hire industry and technology. Uber said it was a deliberate target and if the proposals went ahead they would raise prices and increase congestion in London. Gareth Mead, from Uber, said: "If you think that this is supposed to be a public consultation, well I think the public are not at the

Uber's app connects riders with drivers via GPS, offering lower fares and cashless payments. TfL aims to improve industry standards due to rapid private hire growth. original: Yorkshire batsman Joe Root has been named as new Test captain after Alastair Cook resigned after more than four years in charge. "We need to win but we want to perform in a manner that makes people want to come and watch us," Stokes said. Root's first Test match as England skipper is against South Africa at Lord's beginning on 7 July. The 26-year-old has stepped up from vice-captain, with Durham all-rounder Stokes, 25, filling the role as his deputy. "Test cricket is the pinnacle and we need people to fall in love with it again," added Stokes. Discussing his elevation to vice-captain, he added: "Everything I do is to win and being vice-captain won't change me as a person or as a player. original:
Until now, Google Assistant had only been available on the firm's own Pixel phones. The service, akin to Siri on iPhones, allows users to interact with their devices using voice commands, delivering a hands-free, convenient experience. However, in a bid to make this feature more accessible, Google announced recently that it will be expanding the availability of Google Assistant to a wider range of smartphones.

This strategic move aims to compete directly with Apple's Siri and Amazon's Alexa, offering users of other Android devices the same high-quality, intelligent voice-controlled virtual assistant. This expansion will enable more users to enjoy the benefits of Google Assistant, such as setting reminders, sending texts, or asking for directions, all by just using their voice. 

This initiative places Google at the forefront of the drive to make technology more intuitive and user-friendly. By democratizing this cutting-edge technology, Google is not only reinforcing its commitment to innovation but also to inclusivity, ensuring all Android users can enjoy the benefits of a virtual assistant.

original: The H3 project combines back office services at four police, fire and council authorities in Hampshire and Oxfordshire, to save up to £5m a year. The Police Federation said payroll mistakes were among a "catalogue of errors" since H3 began in 2014. Hampshire's Police and Crime Commissioner (PCC) said the investment would deliver improvements by May. A report to PCC Michael Lane said H3 had caused problems with recruitment and the management of staff sickness, as well as "weighing down" police officers with "back office processes which restrict their effectiveness". In February 2016, 1,300 officers received the wrong pay, while some allowances were wrongly calculated in March. In 2015, the BBC learned that payment delays to Hampshire County Council's suppliers had trebled. under the new system. Ben Butler met a psychologist in 2004 after assaulting a man in a nightclub. Dr Tim Green wrote in his report that Mr Butler found it "difficult to control his anger", which was alarmingly indicative of his pattern of violent behavior. This observation has now resurfaced after Butler was convicted of further violent crimes, highlighting a disappointing failure of the legal and therapeutic systems in managing and averting such cases.

Butler's psychological assessment, made public after recent legal proceedings, underscored the warning signs that were seemingly overlooked. His inability to manage his angry reactions, which led to acts of violence, was not adequately addressed nor were preventive measures put in place.

The case of Ben Butler exposes a larger problem in the system where insufficient attention is given to repeated offenders exhibiting signs of systemic violence. It challenges the efficacy of our rehabilitative measures and prompts a call for more proactive action in managing violent individuals. The system's ability to protect citizens from repeat offenders remains under scrutiny.

Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary (HMIC) said the force had "fragile" staffing levels and needed to "implement more robust human resource strategies."

Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary (HMIC) has issued a stark warning about frailty in police staffing levels, stating that the force currently operates with "fragile" staffing levels and needs to "implement more robust human resource strategies." This recent assessment has thrown light on the intensifying pressure faced by law enforcement agencies around the country, which are grappling with budget cuts and rising crime rates.

The Inspectorate called for immediate action to address the issue, suggesting that workforce planning and recruitment efforts are not keeping pace with the departure or retirement of experienced staff. HMIC emphasized that higher quality leadership and management, coupled with the implementation of a more strategic workforce plan, can help to stave off the staffing crisis.

Public safety is potentially at risk if these concerns are not addressed promptly. The HMIC's findings serve as an urgent call to action for the police forces to bolster their ranks and ensure the public's trust in their ability to maintain law and order.

original: Palmer expects to be fined by the British Horseracing Authority (BHA) for the rule breach during Champions Day. "It was an oversight," Palmer told BBC Sport. "The wrong kit box was left in the lorry and taken to the stables." The Newmarket-based trainer saw Galilieo Gold finish fifth in the Group One Queen Elizabeth II Stakes at Ascot. Horses are only allowed to receive hay-feed or water before a race, but other substances such as electrolytes are permitted post-race. Employees of Palmer and fellow trainers, Francois Rohaut and and Jean-Claude Rouget, as well as the trainers themselves, were interviewed by stewards following a report by the Equine Welfare and Integrity Officer. Palmer is yet to hear what punishment the BHA will hand down. "I imagine there will be a routine fine for a rule that's been broken," he told BBC Radio Berkshire. "There's no suggestion that anyone was trying to seek an advantage or cheat. It's simply what the rule says. The rules are the rules and you need to stick to them."

original: The child, who was under 13, needed medical treatment following the attack by Ajay Jetha last year. A probation report three months earlier warned he might snatch a child "at any time", Leicester Crown Court heard. Jetha, 32, was told he must serve at least 11 years. Updates on this story and more from Leicestershire He previously admitted some offences relating to last year's attack but on Monday changed his plea to guilty to all 10 charges relating to the boy, known only as Child A, which included photographing his assault. He also admitted a further 10 unconnected child sex offences. During the sentencing hearing on Tuesday, it was revealed just three months before the brutal assault in Leicester a Probation Service report said "he could at any time take a child off the street". Speaking after the hearing, Lawrence English, from the Crown Prosecution Service, said: "The police were obviously aware of that [report]

original: Aiden Webb, 22, from Norwich, set off to climb the Fansipan mountain alone on 3 June. He called his girlfriend to say he had fallen, injuring himself. It is understood he later fell down the waterfall while trying to make it to safety. His body was found on 9 June. Tests showed he died at about 07:00 on 4 June, after falling 18m (60ft). More news from Norfolk Mr Webb, an experienced climber, had started his ascent of the 3,100m (10,300ft) high mountain at about 06:00 and planned to climb it in a day. He had gone to Vietnam with his girlfriend Bluebell Baughan, 24, of White Notley, Essex, and she was in contact with him by phone from the nearest town of Sapa. Mr Webb told her he had fallen into a ravine having been forced off the main trail by a landslide. He had cut his arm open on a rock, hurt his knee and lost his

original:
Mr Carney said long-term financing of green projects in emerging markets would promote financial stability. Speaking at an event in Berlin, he urged Germany to lead the global efforts in climate finance. 

Mr Carney said long-term financing of green projects in emerging markets would promote financial stability. Speaking at an event in Berlin, he urged Germany to leverage its economic strength and technological prowess to drive investment in sustainable initiatives worldwide. 

"Germany is in a unique position to steer global markets towards a greener future. This could bring not only environmental benefits but also economic gains, both for Germany and for the emerging countries," Mr Carney said. 

Highlighting the potential of green technology to create jobs and drive economic growth, Carney encouraged German businesses and financial institutions to invest in renewable energy and sustainable infrastructure projects in developing countries. He noted the importance of these investments in achieving the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement.

Carney's message underscores the central role of finance in tackling climate change and promoting sustainable development. It is a call for Germany, Europe's largest economy, to step up and lead the way in the global green finance movement.

original: Meanwhile, Burundian police said they had arrested two foreign journalists who were reporting on armed groups. Violence in the country began last April, when President Pierre Nkurunziza announced he would seek a third term. At least 439 people have died and 240,000 have fled abroad, the UN says. African Union (AU) leaders are due to discuss the crisis in Burundi at a summit in Ethiopia. They want Mr Nkurunziza to accept peacekeeping troops to prevent Burundi sliding into ethnic conflict, but analysts say he is unlikely to agree. Burundi on the brink Tit-for-tat killings spread fear Burundi's football-playing president Presidents who cling to power Amnesty says satellite images show disturbed earth at sites in the Buringa area on the edge of the capital Bujumbura that are consistent with witness reports. "These images suggest a deliberate effort by the authorities to cover up the extent of the killings by their security forces and to prevent the full truth from

original:
Erika Murray, 31, was arrested on Thursday night after a neighbour alerted police over the safety of other children living at the house. Detectives swiftly responded to the call, arriving at the residence to initiate investigation. 

Upon arriving, officers found conditions to be severely neglectful and hazardous. The children present, all under the age of 10, were immediately taken into protective custody due to the apparent immediate threats to their wellbeing. 

While details surrounding the case remain to be fully disclosed, preliminary reports indicate that the children lived amidst squalor, with insufficient food and sanitation. Authorities express their deep concern over the long-term physical and psychological health of the affected children. 

Charged with multiple counts of child endangerment, Murray is set to face a judge early next week. As the investigation continues, authorities are working diligently to ensure the safety and welfare of the children involved. More updates will be provided as this heartbreaking story unfolds.

But Clark's 108 not out from 133 balls and Shivnarine Chanderpaul's steady 85 not out rebuilt the visitor's innings. Clark reached his century with a huge pulled six shortly before the close. Retired West Indies international Chanderpaul put on 55 with Ryan McLaren, calming the innings after the early wickets, before the 42-year-old was joined by Clark when Gareth Batty dismissed McLaren. The pair then shared an unbeaten partnership of 172 with Clark - batting at eight in the order - soon overtaking Chanderpaul's score, beating him to his half-century. original: The party's election manifesto said a funding floor would only be introduced after a referendum was called. The St David's Day Agreement had said the vote would be an "expectation", and Labour Welsh ministers oppose a referendum before a funding deal. Labour accused the Tories of trying to hold them "over a barrel". The manifesto states the Conservatives would "introduce a 'funding floor' to protect Welsh relative funding and provide certainty for the Welsh Government to plan for the future, once it has called a referendum on Income Tax powers in the next Parliament". But a Welsh Conservative spokeswoman told BBC Wales: "The St David's Day commitment we made to introduce a funding floor for Wales is firm and clear, and work is already underway at the Treasury and the Wales Office to bring this floor forward. "The funding floor for Wales is not contingent on an income tax referendum. Our UK manifesto makes clear our expectation that the Welsh Assembly will hold a referendum on income tax raising powers early in the next
variant_1: The party's election manifesto indicated that a funding floor would be implemented only after a referendum is held. The St David's Day Agreement described the vote as an "expectation," with Labour Welsh ministers opposing a referendum prior to securing a funding agreement. Labour accused the Tories of trying to pressure them. The manifesto details that the Conservatives would "introduce a 'funding floor' to safeguard Welsh relative funding and give certainty to the Welsh Government for future planning, once a referendum on Income Tax powers is called in the next Parliament." However, a Welsh Conservative spokeswoman told BBC Wales that the St David's Day commitment to a funding floor is firm and progress is underway at the Treasury and Wales Office to establish it. She emphasized that the funding floor is not dependent on an income tax referendum, and the UK manifesto clearly expects the Welsh Assembly to hold an income tax referendum early in the next term.

original: Tear gas and live bullets were fired to drive back the mainly Shia Muslim crowds, as they protested against corruption and security failures. Officials imposed a curfew in the Iraqi capital, which has now been lifted. It was the second time this month that protesters had managed to break into the city's government area. Shia Muslim cleric Moqtada Sadr condemned the use of force, and voiced support for the demonstrators' "peaceful [and] spontaneous revolt". At least 50 demonstrators are said to have been wounded. The protesters accuse the government of neglecting much-needed reforms, as it struggles with its campaign against the so-called Islamic State group (IS) and declining oil revenues. The Sunni jihadist group controls parts of western and northern Iraq and has been behind a wave of recent attacks that have left dozens killed. Some demonstrators managed to break into the prime minister's office and parliament. Baghdad's Green Zone houses the parliament, key government buildings and many foreign embassies. The authorities later said they had completely regained control of the area and the protesters had withdrawn. The Shia cleric and his militia group, the Mehdi Army, gained prominence after the US-led invasion

The Financial Conduct Authority said these customers were profitable for card providers and so there were few incentives for the firms to intervene. It said customers should be wary and take necessary precautions to safeguard their financial interests. This follows from a recent study on the business practices of card providers, which revealed that their intervention in the financial decisions of profitable customers is minimal, often leading to unchecked spending. 

The FCA urged consumers to be more pro-active about their financial decisions, and not to rely solely on card companies for advice or intervention. It also recommended that customers regularly review their credit card usage and take advantage of financial tools and resources to manage their spending effectively. 

The FCA's statement highlights the need for consumer vigilance in a financial landscape that is often stacked in favor of card providers. The call for consumers to take charge of their financial decisions underscores the importance of financial literacy in today's society.

Entrants to the annual event have five minutes to tell the biggest and most convincing lie they can. Winner George Kemp from Maryport, Cumbria, has been crowned King of Fibs at the annual World's Biggest Liar competition, this year held virtually due to the ongoing pandemic.

Entrants to the annual event have five minutes to tell the biggest and most convincing lie they can. Winner George Kemp from Maryport, Cumbria, spun a remarkable tale about a band of alien frogs that had taken over his town, causing pandemonium as they croaked the national anthem out of tune at all hours. The judging panel was captivated by Kemp's wildly imaginative, yet utterly believable, deception and unanimously deemed him the winner.

original:
North, 24, landed on his head after a high tackle from Adam Thompstone in his side's 19-11 defeat against Leicester Tigers on Saturday. The incident sparked major concern for the player's health as North remained motionless on the pitch for several minutes before being stretchered off.

Medical staff were quick to tend to the rugby star, with early reports suggesting that he may have suffered a concussion. The incident has reignited debates about player safety in rugby, with some calling for stricter enforcement of high-tackle rules.

The Rugby Football Union, the sport's governing body, has announced that it will conduct an immediate review into the incident. 

North's team, Northampton Saints, issued a statement expressing their concern for the player's well-being and promising to support him throughout his recovery. North has a history of concussions, which adds to the collective worry surrounding his recent injury.

This incident underscores the inherent risks of contact sports and calls for a renewed focus on player safety.

OUP analysed more than 120,421 short stories by children aged between five and 13 years old, submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. According to their findings, the creativity and linguistic skill displayed by these budding authors were nothing short of remarkable. 

The stories covered a range of themes, reflecting the concerns, dreams, and fascinations of children across the UK. Climate change, pollution, and animal extinction emerged as prevalent issues, indicating the young participants’ acute awareness of environmental challenges. The narratives also explored themes of adventure, friendship, and family, demonstrating children's understanding of complex emotional dynamics.

The analysis revealed a striking use of vocabulary, with words like 'pandemic,' 'lockdown,' and 'virus' prominent, reflecting the influence of the Covid-19 crisis on children's lives. Additionally, an increase in the use of technology-related words was observed. 

This research underscores the power of storytelling as a medium for children to express their perceptions and understanding of the

original: The deal unveiled by Russia on Thursday to set up four "de-escalation zones" is backed by Turkey and Iran. But the main Syrian opposition grouping says it has little faith in the deal. Elsewhere in Syria, activists say government aircraft have hit central Hama province, and there are reports of shelling and gunfire in other parts. The opposition High Negotiations Committee (HNC), said on Friday the safe zones plan lacked "safeguards and compliance mechanisms". It also said it did not accept Iran as a guarantor of the deal. The UN special envoy for Syria, Staffan de Mistura, told the BBC the agreement was important because it was being implemented by three countries who could make it work. The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) said Syrian fighter jets on Saturday bombed rebel positions in Hama. A rebel commander confirmed that fighting had broken out after midnight, Reuters reports. The Syrian military have so far not commented on the issue. Seamer Abbott, 29, and top-order batsman Rossouw, 27, confirmed their international retirements in January. The young duo's decision to withdraw from the international cricket circuit came as a surprise to many fans and critics alike. Abbott, known for his steely consistency, and Rossouw, renowned for his tenacity at the crease, have been significant contributors to their national teams. 

The decision to retire early is understood to be a personal choice for both players, motivated by a desire to focus on their domestic careers. Their retirement has sparked a fresh debate on the increasing demands of international cricket on players' physical and mental health.

However, their departure from the international scene does not mean a complete disappearance from the cricket field. Both players plan to continue playing at the domestic level, bringing their skills and experience to benefit their local teams. As cricket enthusiasts bid farewell to the international careers of these talented players, they look forward to witnessing their continued contributions to the sport.

original: The launch of what was supposed to be its flagship model has turned into a fiasco for the world's largest smartphone maker. As the South Korean company scrambles to contain the crisis, we look back at the developments so far: 2 August: Samsung unveils its latest flagship model Galaxy Note 7 amid great fanfare in New York. The phone is packed with new features like an iris scanner. The initial response is good and expectations high. It's seen as Samsung's big rival to the upcoming iPhone 7. 19 August: Sales start in 10 markets, including South Korea and the United States. European markets are scheduled for October. 24 August: The first report of a Note 7 device "exploding" appear in the news. It isn't long before there are more incidents with users posting pictures and videos of what they say are their phones overheating, exploding or catching fire. 2 September: Samsung announces a voluntary global recall of some 2.5 million Note 7 phones, citing faulty batteries. The company
variant_1: The rollout of what was intended to be Samsung's flagship smartphone has become a disaster for the world's biggest phone manufacturer. As the South Korean firm rushes to manage the fallout, let's review the key events so far: On August 2, Samsung launched its latest flagship, the Galaxy Note 7, with much excitement in New York. The device featured innovations such as an iris scanner, received positive initial feedback, and was positioned as a strong competitor to the upcoming iPhone 7. On August 19, sales began in 10 countries, including South Korea and the U.S., with European releases planned for October. By August 24, reports emerged of Note 7 devices catching fire or exploding, accompanied by user-shared images and videos. On September 2, Samsung declared a voluntary global recall of approximately 2.5 million Note 7 units due to defective batteries.
variant_2: What was meant to be Samsung's premier smartphone launch turned into a significant blunder for the leading global smartphone maker. The phone included advanced features like an iris scanner, with a positive initial reception and high expectations as a major competitor to the iPhone 7. Sales commenced on August 19 in 10 markets, including South Korea and the U.S., with Europe expected to follow in October. By August 24, the first reports surfaced of Note 7 units exploding, soon followed by multiple incidents shared by users showing phones overheating, bursting into flames, or exploding. On September 2, Samsung announced a voluntary worldwide recall of about 2.5 million Note 7 phones due to faulty batteries.

On August 24, reports surfaced of Note 7 devices exploding, soon followed by multiple incidents with users posting pictures and videos of phones overheating, catching fire, or exploding. On September 2, Samsung issued a voluntary global recall of around 2.5 million Note 7 phones due to faulty batteries.

The phone featured new technology such as an iris scanner and received a positive initial response, positioned as a strong competitor to the forthcoming iPhone 7. Sales started on August 19 in 10 markets including South Korea and the U.S., with Europe scheduled for October. By August 24, the first reports of exploding Note 7 devices appeared, followed by users sharing pictures and videos of phones overheating, catching fire, or exploding. On September 2, Samsung announced a voluntary global recall of some 2.5 million Note 7 phones due to faulty batteries.

original: The A320 pilot reported seeing a white quadcopter drone "flash past" the aircraft while travelling south of Brookmans Park last August. No avoiding action was possible due to the lack of available time, a UK Airprox Board report said. It concluded a "collision had only been narrowly avoided and chance had played a major part". Air traffic control said the A320 pilot reported that "something had just gone over the top of him" at about 18:45 BST on 15 August 2016 while flying north of Potters Bar. The controller said another aircraft had just crossed above but the pilot said the object was red and white in colour, had red and blue stripes on two of the rotor arms and was under a metre in size. original: Gene Palmer is the second prison worker detained over the jail break. Joyce Mitchell has already been charged with aiding the escape. The prisoners, Richard Matt and David Sweat, used power tools to flee the Clinton Correctional Facility. A massive manhunt is still under way to find the pair, both convicted killers. Mr Palmer has been held on bail, after appearing before a judge on charges of promoting prison contraband, tampering with physical evidence, and official misconduct. His lawyer, Andrew Brockway, admitted his client delivered the meat but said he did not know it contained the tools, nor that the prisoners were trying to escape. "He did pass the hamburger meat. He shouldn't have done it. He apologised for it,'' said Mr Brockway, who added his client plans to plead not guilty. Clinton County District Attorney Andrew Wylie said Ms Mitchell placed hacksaw blades and other tools inside the meat, before Mr Palmer took it to Matt and Sweat, who were interred in a section of the jail where prisoners can cook their own meals. Meanwhile, officers are concentrating their search on a 75 sq mi (194 sq km) area of northern New

Mr. Palmer was released on bail after appearing before a judge on charges including promoting prison contraband, tampering with evidence, and official misconduct. He shouldn't have done it. He apologized for it," said Brockway, who added Palmer intends to plead not guilty. original: The changes would allow Japanese troops to fight abroad for the first time since World War Two. The legislation has already been passed by Japan's lower house and is expected to be endorsed by the upper chamber. Under its constitution, Japan is barred from using force to resolve conflicts except in cases of self-defence. But a reinterpretation of the law will now allow "collective self-defence" - using force to defend allies under attack. Police are lining the streets and telling protesters to move along in an attempt to minimise disruption in the capital's centre. Despite the wet weather conditions, tens of thousands of protesters poured out onto the streets demanding that their pacifist constitution be protected and calling for the prime minister to step down. The streets were lined with police vans but given how unprecedented it is for the Japanese to be so vocal, there was never any fear

The legislation has cleared Japan's lower house and is anticipated to be approved by the upper house. Japan's constitution prohibits the use of force to settle disputes except in self-defense cases, but a new legal reinterpretation now permits "collective self-defense," meaning using force to protect allies under attack. Police are patrolling the streets, urging protesters to disperse to reduce disruption in the capital's center. Despite rainy weather, tens of thousands marched demanding the preservation of Japan's pacifist constitution and calling for the prime minister's resignation. Police vans lined the streets, but the unprecedented vocal protests by Japanese citizens did not generate fear.

original:
The number given for the current account customers hit by the fraud is fewer than half of the 20,000 initially reported to have been affected. Personal information and account numbers were exposed in a sophisticated scam, causing widespread panic among account holders. 

The breach, orchestrated by a group of cybercriminals, initially appeared to have impacted one in every hundred customers of the major bank. However, following rigorous investigations by the cybercrime department, the actual figure was revised down to less than 10,000. 

The bank assured that they have taken immediate action to safeguard those affected, including resetting passwords and monitoring accounts for suspicious activity. They also urged customers to remain vigilant, stressing the importance of not sharing sensitive information via email or over the phone.

In a statement, the bank said, "We deeply regret the concern and inconvenience this incident may have caused. We are committed to protecting our customers' data and have taken steps to prevent such incidents in the future."

original:
Officers at first did not treat Stephen Phillips's death as suspicious after he was found in his Wolverhampton flat. His family became suspicious when they discovered unusual transactions in his bank account, leading to a deeper investigation into his sudden demise.

The Phillips family noted several withdrawals that appeared to be out of character for Stephen, who was known as a meticulous and careful individual, especially concerning his finances. This alarming discovery prompted them to request authorities for a more thorough investigation into his death.

Upon their request, the West Midlands Police launched a more substantial inquiry, utilising the full extent of their forensic capabilities. The startling results revealed the presence of a rare toxin in his system, suggesting foul play. This shocking turn of events has devastated the family and friends of Stephen Phillips.

The police have since arrested a suspect linked to the unusual transactions in Stephen's bank account. However, the investigation is ongoing. This tragic revelation serves as a reminder of the importance of vigilance in our everyday lives, even in seemingly ordinary circumstances

original:
Geoffrey Stewart, 74, of Dumfries, was one of three men in their 60s and 70s who went missing in the Scottish highlands yesterday. Geoffrey Stewart, 74, of Dumfries, was one of three men in their 60s and 70s who went missing in the treacherous terrain of the Highlands, sparking a large-scale search and rescue operation.

The trio, all experienced hikers, were last seen embarking on a walking trail near Ben Nevis, Britain’s highest peak, early Tuesday morning. Alarm bells rang after they failed to return to their lodging by late evening, which was unusual given their hiking routine.

Mountain rescue teams from Fort William, Lochaber, and Skye, as well as a coastguard helicopter, were deployed for the search operation. Despite challenging weather conditions, including heavy rain, strong winds, and low visibility, the search teams have remained optimistic.

original: Christopher Kelly, 40, strangled his friend Dorothy Beattie, 51, at her home in Dunoon, Argyll and Bute, on 22 May. The High Court in Glasgow heard he attacked her after she allegedly made a jibe about his children. Kelly, who was caught after confessing to a GP, was originally charged with murder but pleaded guilty to the lesser charge of culpable homicide. The court heard how Kelly had previously been a support worker for Ms Beattie, who suffered from a number of medical conditions including seizures. The divorced mother and Kelly later became friends and often socialised together. The social care graduate attacked her at her home, however, after she allegedly made "derogatory" remarks about his children. Kelly grabbed Ms Beattie and strangled her before leaving the flat. The series will be another co-production with US network AMC, following their joint effort on The Night Manager.
