The Spy Who Came In From The Cold is set in 1962, months after the building of the Berlin Wall. original:
Julia Knight, 56, denies attempting to murder Irene Robson, 81, at Horton Hospital in Banbury in October 2014, but admits to causing grievous bodily harm. Knight, a former nurse, was charged in connection to an incident involving her elderly patient, Irene Robson, at Horton Hospital in Banbury in October 2014. She is accused of administering a non-prescribed dosage of drugs, leading to a significant deterioration in Robson's health.

Knight, however, maintains her innocence, vehemently denying the accusation of attempted murder. She does, however, admit to causing harm, albeit unintentionally. The defense argues Knight's actions were a result of professional negligence, not a premeditated attempt to end a life.

The case has sent shockwaves through the medical community in Banbury, reigniting debates on patient safety and the heavy responsibility healthcare professionals bear. The trial continues at the Oxford Crown Court, where Knight faces possible conviction. The outcome of the case is being closely watched, not just by those directly involved, but also by professionals in the healthcare sector nationwide.

original: NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT) said blood group O negative was vital, as it could be used for patients with other blood groups in an emergency. It said O negative blood made up 12% of transfers, although only 7% of people in the UK had that blood type. Meanwhile, B negative blood is needed for ethnic groups. The NHSBT said ethnic minority groups, who were more likely to have B negative blood, were more prone to sickle cell anaemia, where misshapen blood cells could block blood vessels, causing an early death. It also said such groups were more at risk of developing thalassemia, a group of inherited blood disorders that hindered the blood's ability to carry oxygen. Only 2% of Britain's population were B negative, but hospitals had used 6% more of this blood type in the past last four weeks than the same period last year, said the NHSBT. B negative blood was useful as it could be used for both B negative and B positive patients,

original:
Charles Blackman's oil work Women Lovers features two nude women resting on a bed beside a cat. Art broker Mossgreen attempted to promote this intricate piece in an effort to highlight the emotional depth of Blackman's work. The painting, characterized by its expressive strokes and muted tones, is thought to be one of Blackman's more intimate depictions of the human form. 

This particular artwork has long been admired for its tender portrayal of affection between women, a theme not often explored in the mid-20th century. The cat, a recurring motif in Blackman's work, adds an element of mystery and intrigue. 

Blackman's fascination with the dynamics of relationships and the complexity of human emotions is brilliantly echoed in this oil painting. This promotion by Mossgreen was not just an attempt to sell an artwork, but an endeavor to showcase the depth and sensitivity of Blackman's vision. The subtle elegance in Women Lovers offers a glimpse into the artist's understanding of love, intimacy

original: Thomas, 28, is a key member of the Team Sky side trying to guide Chris Froome to a second successive Tour title. Froome has already been sent for an X-ray after a crash during the fourth stage of the Tour de France. "On the cobbles it's sketchy anyway. If it does rain it could end somebody's race quite easily," said Thomas. "You train all year for this and for it to end like that would be devastating for whoever it was. "So hopefully it stays dry and everyone stays out of trouble." Froome touched wheels in the peloton and fell just five kilometres into the 163.5km fourth stage between Le Touquet-Paris-Place and Lille Metropole. The 29-year-old suffered a grazed left hip and wrist injury, before quickly getting back on his bike and rejoining the peloton, after receiving medical attention from the race doctor. He is in seventh place overall, two seconds behind race leader Vincenzo Nibali after stage four was won by Marcel Kittel. Wednesday's stage begins in the Belgian city of Ypres and ends 155.5km away in Arenberg-Porte

original: Over the next few years Forest Enterprise Scotland will plant them around Loch Trool and the Cree Valley. It is hoped the acorns should help to grow about 600,000 young trees creating a "large and vibrant habitat". Environment forester Gareth Ventress said that as soon as they had seen they were in for a "bumper crop" of acorns they began planning to collect them. "We also decided to get help from other staff throughout Scotland and asked them to collect acorns from other native oak woods found on the national forest estate," he said. "The Cree Valley Community Woodland Trust, Borders Forest Trust and Moffat Community Woodlands all assisted in the big collection too in order to further native woodland expansion across their project areas in south Scotland. "By combining acorns collected from across Galloway Forest Park, we increase the genetic diversity of the trees linking the remnant woodlands. "This is vital for creating robust and resilient woodlands that can handle pests and diseases well into the future." The
variant_1: Over the coming years, Forest Enterprise Scotland plans to plant acorns around Loch Trool and the Cree Valley, aiming to grow approximately 600,000 young trees to establish a large, thriving habitat. Environment forester Gareth Ventress explained that once they realized they were expecting a bumper acorn crop, they started organizing collection efforts. They enlisted help from staff across Scotland to gather acorns from native oak woods on the national forest estate. Additionally, the Cree Valley Community Woodland Trust, Borders Forest Trust, and Moffat Community Woodlands supported the extensive collection to promote native woodland growth in southern Scotland. By pooling acorns from Galloway Forest Park, genetic diversity is enhanced, linking isolated woodlands. This diversity is crucial for developing strong, resilient forests capable of resisting pests and diseases in the future.

This genetic variety is essential for building resilient woodlands able to withstand pests and diseases long-term.

original:
Aiden Webb, 22, from Norwich, set off to climb the Fansipan Mountain alone on 3 June. He called his girlfriend to say he had fallen and injured himself, sparking a frantic search for him in the rugged Vietnamese terrain. Webb is a seasoned adventurer, known for his prowess in outdoor sports and mountain climbing, making the news of his accident all the more shocking to those who know him.

His girlfriend, Bluebell Baughan, immediately alerted the authorities, sparking a search and rescue operation that spanned several days. Tragically, Webb's body was discovered by local search teams on Tuesday, ending the desperate search. Aiden was known for his love of nature, outdoor adventure, and his vibrant spirit. His untimely death has left a deep void in the global outdoor adventure community.

His family and girlfriend are devastated but grateful for the outpouring of support from the public. The British consulate is providing consular support to his family and working with local authorities

original: Research for the College of Policing suggested that officers were focusing on cases involving violence and overlooking other risk factors. Three unnamed police forces in England and Wales are taking part in a pilot scheme following the study. Coercive or controlling behaviour became a criminal offence last year. The research found that although most domestic abuse incidents were handled in a "professional" way, some officers still displayed "negative and uninformed" attitudes. In particular, police tended to neglect cases where suspects did not use violence but tried to control their victim in other ways such as by making threats. The report said: "A tendency for the police to focus on physical violence and what has occurred at the current incident can result in them missing abuse which is characterised not by physical violence and injury but by continuous coercion and control in other forms." The researchers concluded that if risk was not assessed properly some cases would "slip through the net". In response, the College of Policing is setting up a pilot scheme to help officers identify possible patterns of abusive behaviour. David Tucker, the college's lead
variant_1: Research conducted for the College of Policing indicated that officers were prioritizing cases involving violence while neglecting other risk factors. Three unnamed police forces in England and Wales are participating in a pilot program following the study. Coercive or controlling behavior was criminalized last year. The research revealed that although most domestic abuse cases were managed professionally, some officers still exhibited negative and uninformed attitudes. Specifically, police often overlooked cases where suspects did not use violence but exerted control through threats or other means. The report stated that focusing on physical violence and recent incidents could cause police to miss abuse characterized by ongoing coercion and control without physical violence. Researchers concluded that improper risk assessment could allow some cases to be overlooked. To address this, the College of Policing is launching a pilot scheme to help officers recognize patterns of abusive behavior. David Tucker, the college's lead, commented on the initiative.

original:
The new charity will manage the National Heritage Collection, which includes iconic historical sites such as Stonehenge and Dover Castle. The government currently contributes £22m annually towards the upkeep and conservation of these sites of national significance. 

The charity, set to take over from the government, has promised to maintain the integrity of these historical markers and increase their accessibility to the public. The change in management hopes to bring a renewed focus on community engagement, education, and historical preservation. 

The government's annual contribution will continue under the new arrangement, ensuring the longevity and preservation of the National Heritage Collection. The charity plans to supplement this funding with private donations, corporate sponsorships, and revenue from increased visitor numbers. 

This development signals an exciting new era for the National Heritage Collection, offering a fresh perspective on the management of these treasured sites, while ensuring they continue to hold a proud place in Britain’s cultural landscape.

Currently, the government provides £22 million annually for the maintenance and preservation of these nationally important locations.

original: Maj Richard Scott, 40, is accused of driving at speeds of up to 95mph (153km/h) in bad weather before the smash on a B-road in Wiltshire. Gareth Hicks, 24, suffered fatal injuries when the van he was asleep in was hit by Mr Scott's Audi A6. Maj Scott denies a charge of causing death by careless driving. Prosecutor Charles Gabb alleged the defendant, from Green Lane in Shepperton, Surrey, had crossed the carriageway of the 60mph-limit B390 in Shrewton near Amesbury. The weather was "awful" and there was strong wind and rain, he told jurors. He said Mr Scott's car was described as "twitching" and "may have been aquaplaning" before striking the first vehicle; a BMW driven by Craig Reed. Mr Scott's Audi then returned to his side of the road but crossed the carriageway again before colliding head-on with a Ford Transit van in which Mr Hicks was a passenger, the
variant_1: Major Richard Scott, 40, is accused of driving at speeds up to 95mph (153km/h) in poor weather conditions before a crash on a B-road in Wiltshire. Gareth Hicks, 24, died after the van he was sleeping in was hit by Scott's Audi A6. Maj Scott denies causing death by careless driving. Prosecutor Charles Gabb claimed the defendant, from Green Lane in Shepperton, Surrey, crossed the carriageway of the 60mph-limit B390 near Shrewton by Amesbury. The weather was terrible with strong wind and rain, the prosecutor told jurors. Mr Scott's car was said to be "twitching" and possibly aquaplaning before hitting a BMW driven by Craig Reed. Scott's Audi then moved back to his side but crossed again, crashing head-on with a Ford Transit van carrying Mr Hicks.

original:
The proposals are believed to include tougher English language requirements for students. Dominic Scott, head of the UK Council for International Student Affairs, said it would be a significant step forward in elevating the quality of international education in the UK. The proposals are believed to include tougher English language requirements for students. This move comes in response to concerns that some international students lack sufficient English proficiency to fully engage in their chosen academic courses.

Scott stated, "Higher English proficiency standards can ensure students not only succeed acadically but also integrate better into the local community and culture." Critics argue that the move could deter potential students from applying to UK universities. However, Scott countered that it will attract students genuinely interested in improving their language skills and learning.

The proposal forms part of a wider government initiative to uphold the integrity and quality of UK higher education amidst increasing global competition. It's hoped that these changes might also encourage UK students to consider studying foreign languages, fostering a more global outlook in the nation's youth. The proposal is yet to receive final approval and is currently under review.

original:
The furry feline has been a familiar face on the steps outside Number 10's black door since he moved in, in 2011. And the nation's beloved cat, Larry, has not only become a beloved figure in his own right, but an emblem of political stability amidst years of political turbulence. 

This charismatic Chief Mouser has witnessed the comings and goings of three prime ministers, adding an amusing and heartwarming fixture to the often high-tension world of politics. Larry, a brown and white tabby, was recruited from Battersea Dogs & Cats Home with a clear mission: to keep Downing Street pest-free. 

However, his duties have expanded over the years to include photo ops, greeting guests, and appearing on international television. His fame has spread far beyond the UK, with fans across the globe following his antics via social media updates. Larry proves that even in the midst of political upheaval, a furry friend can provide comfort and continuity.

original: The girl, who has Smith-Magenis Syndrome, was arrested four times and twice held overnight in police stations. Her mother complained about her treatment to the Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC). Sussex Police said it welcomed the IPCC scrutiny and supported its inquiry. The girl came into contact with police between 2 February and 2 March last year in Horsham, West Sussex. She was held under under the mental health act on 9 February, arrested on suspicion of assault seven days later, held over a public order offence on 29 February and arrested in connection with criminal damage on 2 March. The girl's mother complained in July 2012 about the methods of restraint used on her daughter, which the IPCC said appeared to have included handcuffs and leg restraints, and the decisions to hold her in police cells overnight. original:
The Port Talbot-based Specific innovation centre is working on the concept of "buildings as power stations". The project involves Tata Steel, Swansea University and AkzoNobel. 

The Port Talbot-based Specific Innovation Centre is working on the revolutionary concept of "buildings as power stations". An ambitious project, it is a collaborative effort involving Tata Steel, Swansea University and AkzoNobel, aiming to create a sustainable future for the construction industry.

At its core, the project aims to develop buildings that can generate, store, and release their own solar energy. This innovative approach to energy production and consumption could transform the way we perceive and use buildings.

Tata Steel provides the building materials, Swansea University brings its expertise in solar energy research, while AkzoNobel, a global paint and coatings company, ensures the buildings are not only energy efficient but aesthetically pleasing as well.

The Specific innovation Centre's project offers a glimpse into a sustainable future where buildings contribute to energy production rather than being solely consumers of it. It marks a significant step towards a greener and more sustainable construction sector, providing a model that could be replicated worldwide

Mrs Foster said on Wednesday that she wanted to better understand those who love the language. She said she wanted to "listen to and engage with those who love the language" in reference to her new initiative aimed at promoting cultural diversity and inclusivity.

Mrs Foster said on Wednesday that she wanted to better understand those who love the language. She said she wanted to "listen to and engage with those who use, promote, and cherish the language every day." This statement marks a significant shift in her previously held stance, signaling a more inclusive approach to understanding and appreciating the cultural and linguistic diversity within our community.

The initiative, dubbed "Listening to Languages", is expected to involve several engagement activities, including language workshops, cultural exchange programs, and public forums, geared towards promoting understanding and respect for all languages and cultures.

In her announcement, Mrs. Foster emphasized, "The love for language transcends borders and barriers. It is our collective responsibility to understand, respect and celebrate this diversity. I hope this initiative will foster a new appreciation for the richness language brings to our lives."

Unemployment fell to 1.69 million between January and March, down 2,000 from the previous quarter. The jobless rate remained at 4.9%, according to the latest figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS). This static rate reflects the stability in the UK job market, despite ongoing economic uncertainties. 

The numbers signify that the UK economy continues to display resilience, maintaining a relatively low level of unemployment. Economists have noted the robustness of the job market, attributing it to a combination of flexible working arrangements and sustained consumer spending. 

However, experts have also pointed out that while the overall unemployment figures are positive, they do not explicitly reflect the quality of work available. Underemployment and the prevalence of zero-hour contracts are ongoing issues, which the headline figures fail to address. 

These statistics underpin the complex reality of the job market, which, while demonstrating overall strength and stability, also reveals areas that require significant improvement. Further investigation into improving employment quality, not just quantity, is needed to assure a truly healthy economy.

original: The walk-in service is aimed at reducing doctor appointments and to help reduce the over-use of antibiotics, NHS England said. It is hoped the scheme could result in fewer visits to GPs -potentially saving the NHS millions of pounds a year. But pharmacies say cuts in funding to the sector could jeopardise the scheme. The Sore Throat Test and Treat service, which has been trialled in 35 Boots pharmacies, will determine if an illness is caused by a virus - meaning drugs will not help - or a bacterial infection. Results from a throat swab, which measures sugars on the tongue, are provided in five minutes. Patients who can be helped by antibiotics will be prescribed them by the pharmacist and not have to see a GP. NHS chief executive Simon Stevens said the scheme will be rolled out across the country over the coming year. Dr Adam Roberts, a microbiologist at University College London specialising in antibiotic resistance, told the BBC it was "quite an innovative step". He said: "Anything that

original: A survey of employees and managers found that a quarter of new fathers took no paternity leave at all. Fewer than one in 10 took more than their two weeks statutory leave. The research by the Institute of Leadership & Management (ILM) blamed "ingrained" attitudes among employers, and concerns among new fathers that they could not afford to take leave. Last year the government announced plans to allow parents to share their maternity and paternity leave - changes are scheduled to come in April 2015. But the ILM said its research suggested the changes would have little impact if attitudes of employers were not addressed as well. "The introduction of shared parental leave is a crucial step towards enabling more women to progress into senior roles," said Charles Elvin, ILM chief executive. "Yet our research revealed cultural barriers are impeding the uptake of both two weeks statutory paternity leave and additional paternity leave." He said there remained a "cultural expectation" within organisations that women rather than men will be the ones taking extended periods away from the workplace. The report also said low levels of paternity pay discouraged new fathers,

original: Scot Higgins, 19, started his youth career at Celtic before moving to Dens Park and made four appearances for Dundee last season. Former Republish of Ireland Under-21 player Power, 29, leaves English League Two club Lincoln City, where he made over 250 league appearances. Both players have agreed two-year contracts with the Rugby Park club, with Power's move subject to clearance. "It feels good to be here, as it's a club that's definitely going in the right direction," Higgins told Kilmarnock's website. Manager Lee McCulloch said Higgins fits Kilmarnock's philosophy of developing young players. "He came through Celtic's academy, which has seen many impressive young players come through," said McCulloch. "For the second half of last season he gained experience at Dundee and through time will only get better, which is only a good thing for this club." And Power said: "I've heard a lot about the town and the club's history and I can't wait to get started. The manager spoke about his visions for this club and it was an easy decision to make." McCulloch said he watch Lincoln's run to the quarter-finals of the FA

original:
Maj Richard Scott, 40, is accused of driving at speeds of up to 95mph (153km/h) in bad weather before the shocking accident that resulted in severe injuries to a pedestrian late last Tuesday. The incident occurred along a notorious stretch of the M4 highway, renowned for treacherous conditions during heavy rainfall. Police reports suggest that Scott, a decorated military officer, lost control of his vehicle due to excessive speed and poor visibility, striking a 52-year-old man who was immediately rushed to the hospital in critical condition. 

The Major now faces potential charges of reckless driving and causing serious bodily harm. He was released on bail awaiting a court hearing. The accident has prompted local authorities to reconsider safety measures on the M4, including the possibility of lowering speed limits during inclement weather. This tragic accident serves as a stark reminder of the vital importance of road safety, particularly in adverse weather conditions.

Remus Hamza, 40, is alleged to have attacked a 20-year-old woman near Cardiff University as she walked home alone after a night out. The incident, which reportedly took place at the end of last week, has sent shockwaves through the local community and university campus.

The victim, whose identity has been kept anonymous for her protection, was thankfully able to escape the ordeal without life-threatening injuries. However, she is said to be in a state of trauma following the incident. Local authorities were alerted and quickly initiated an investigation.

Hamza was arrested on charges of sexual assault and public intoxication. As of now, he remains in police custody, awaiting a court hearing.

This incident has spurred discussions about safety, particularly for female students in the area. Cardiff University and local police are said to be stepping up security measures on and around the campus to ensure the well-being of its students. Students are being advised to be more vigilant and take necessary precautions while out at night.

original:
A train travelling from Penzance to Exeter collided with another train on platform six just after 15.30 BST on 3 April. The Rail Accident Investigation Branch is currently investigating the incident.

A train travelling from Penzance to Exeter collided with another train on platform six just after 15.30 BST on 3 April. The Rail Accident Investigation Branch has been called in to understand the circumstances leading to the crash. The collision occurred at lower speed, resulting in minor structural damage to both trains but no significant injuries to passengers or crew.

British Transport Police and local emergency services responded promptly, evacuating the station and rerouting incoming trains. As a result, significant delays and disruptions were experienced throughout the network.

The station has been closed temporarily until a thorough inspection is completed to ensure the tracks' safety. The train company apologised to all passengers affected by the incident and promised to conduct a full investigation.

Falcon and Pointer was fined £175,000 for making automated calls about PPI, and Direct Choice Home Improvements Ltd was fined £50,000 for nuisance calls. This comes as part of a continuing clamping down by the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) on companies breaching privacy laws. Falcon and Pointer were accused of making over 2.5 million automated calls about PPI claims, causing significant distress and annoyance to the recipients. In fact, the ICO received 5,535 complaints about the company's practices. 

Similarly, Direct Choice Home Improvements Ltd was hit with a hefty fine following 168 complaints about unsolicited marketing calls made to people who had specifically opted out of receiving such communications. The ICO is showing its commitment to protect the privacy and rights of individuals from companies that disregard the law. These fines should serve as a stark warning to other companies engaging in similar practices - they could be next in the ICO's line of fire. The public is advised to report any nuisance calls to the ICO.

The Crawick Multiverse, designed by renowned artist Charles Jencks, has been created with materials found on the site in Dumfries and Galloway. 

The Crawick Multiverse, designed by renowned artist Charles Jencks, has been created with materials found on the site in Dumfries and Galloway. This large scale public art installation, sprawled over 55 acres, is a riveting blend of science, art, and landscape design. It showcases Jenck's unique vision, transforming what was once a deserted coal mine into an astonishing testament to the mysteries of the cosmos. 

The site features a myriad of sculptures and landforms, symbolizing cosmic concepts and scientific theories. Highlights include the Multiverse, the Comet Walk, and representations of black holes. These are all constructed using stones, earth and other materials found on site, reflecting Jencks' commitment to sustainability and environmental harmony. 

Thousands of visitors are drawn each year to this captivating space, which marries natural beauty with intellectual wonder. The Crawick Multiverse serves not only as a testament to Jencks' artistic prowess but also as an educational site,

The H3 project combines back office services at four police, fire, and council authorities in Hampshire and Oxfordshire, aiming to save up to £5m per annum. This revolutionary approach to public service collaboration involves Hampshire Constabulary, Hampshire Fire and Rescue Service, Oxfordshire County Council, and Hampshire County Council. 

The collaboration is a bold move to streamline operations and reduce costs while maintaining the highest levels of service. By sharing resources and integrating services such as HR, finance, and procurement, the H3 project is expected to significantly enhance operational efficiency. 

"By working together and sharing services, we can reduce costs and reinvest in frontline services," said a spokesperson for the H3 project. 

As public services face ongoing financial challenges, innovative solutions such as the H3 project are vital. The potential £5m annual savings could be channelled back into essential public services, ensuring sustainability and improved service delivery for the residents of Hampshire and Oxfordshire. original: Mr Carney said long-term financing of green projects in emerging markets would promote financial stability. Speaking at an event in Berlin, he urged Germany to use its G20 presidency in 2017 to make progress. Mr Carney has previously warned of climate change risks for the finance industry. At the event on Thursday, Mr Carney said that in theory capital should flow from advanced to emerging economies due to high returns. In practice, however, the opposite has happened - and this has driven down bond yields in advanced economies, he said. When money has sporadically flowed to emerging economies it has had a destabilising influence, he said. "In this context, green finance is a major opportunity. By ensuring that capital flows finance long-term projects in countries where growth is most carbon intensive, financial stability can be promoted," he said. Mr Carney said the issuance of green bonds - for example, to help finance water or renewable power projects aimed at reducing carbon emissions - could double in 2016 from last year's $42bn. But they still represent only 1% of holdings by global financial institutions, he said. "The development of this new global asset
variant_1: Mr Carney stated that long-term funding for green initiatives in emerging markets would enhance financial stability. Speaking in Berlin, he encouraged Germany to leverage its 2017 G20 presidency to advance this cause. He had previously highlighted climate change risks to the finance sector. At Thursday's event, he noted that capital should theoretically move from developed to emerging economies due to higher returns, but the reverse has occurred, lowering bond yields in developed nations. Sporadic capital inflow to emerging markets has caused instability. He emphasized green finance as a crucial opportunity to channel funds into long-term projects in carbon-intensive growth countries, thereby promoting financial stability. Mr Carney mentioned that green bond issuance, such as for water or renewable energy projects reducing carbon emissions, might double in 2016 from $42bn in 2015, though they still make up only 1% of global financial institutions' holdings. original:
The last print edition will be on 31 December, reflecting the trend for newspapers and magazines to move online as traditional advertising declines. Newsweek merged with the The Daily Beast in 2010.

The last print edition will be on 31 December, reflecting the trend for newspapers and magazines to move online as traditional advertising declines. Newsweek merged with the Daily Beast in 2010 in an attempt to consolidate resources and expand its digital presence. The decision to end the print edition marks another milestone in the industry's shift towards digital media. The move comes amid the steady decline of print circulation and advertising revenue, a challenge that has been confronting the publishing industry for years. 

Newsweek plans to continue publishing digital versions of its magazine, focusing on its online subscription model while still delivering the quality journalism it is known for.

The shift to digital reflects the reality of our digital-first world and the changing consumer behavior. While this decision might disappoint print-version lovers, it’s a necessary adaptation for the survival and growth of media institutions in this digital era. Newsweek, in its new avatar, aims to continue to inform, engage and inspire readers around the world.

original: The furry feline has been a familiar face on the steps outside Number 10's black door since he moved in, in 2011. And the "chief mouser" will stay when Theresa May replaces Mr Cameron as UK prime minister. "It's a civil servant's cat and does not belong to the Camerons - he will be staying," a government spokesman said. The tabby cat, from London's Battersea Cats and Dogs Home, was brought in to Downing Street in 2011 tasked with tackling a rat problem, after a large black rat was seen scuttling past the No 10's front door in the background of a live TV broadcast. Said to have a "strong predatory drive" and enjoy playing with mouse toys, Larry was considered to be well-suited to the post. original: Gabon was selected as host on Wednesday by the Confederation of African Football's Executive Committee, beating rival candidates Ghana and Algeria. "We will prepare ourselves to win the Nations Cup in 2017," said Gabon football official Jean-Felix Mba Nze. "We have decided to play and win the cup." Gabon first entered the Nations Cup in 1970 but failed to qualify for the finals until 1994. Their best results came when reaching the quarter-finals in 1996 and 2012, a tournament they co-hosted with Equatorial Guinea. During this year's Nations Cup, which also took place in Equatorial Guinea, the Panthers crashed out early after winning one and losing two of their group games. The 2017 Nations Cup will be the first time Gabon has staged the finals by itself. The successful launch of the KSLV-1, also known as Naro, underpins South Korea's ambitious plans to become a major player in the multibillion-dollar space industry.

The KSLV-1, the first space vehicle completely built on native Korean technology, soared into the sky, leaving a trail of fire and smoke, and carrying the hopes of a nation that is keen on strengthening its foothold in space exploration. The launch comes amid growing global interest in space science and industry, with several countries and private enterprises vying for a slice of the lucrative space market.

Harrison, 24, lasted just half an hour in England's last Test match against Australia in Sydney. "He's gone back and worked on his game very hard," Jones told BBC Sport. "His last game against Castres was exceptional and he's probably our number one choice open-side flanker at the moment." Wood was dropped following the Rugby World Cup, with Jones telling him his performances were "distinctly average". original: The woman repeatedly reported Craig Hutsby, of Eastwood, Nottinghamshire, for threatening behaviour and breach of bail conditions in July 2014. The following month Hutsby raped her. The IPCC report revealed the attack could have been prevented had arrest forms been filled out immediately. Det Supt Rachel Walker said officers had attended misconduct meetings. The Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC) concluded that PC Sofi Essex has a case to answer for misconduct for not creating an "arrest package" - paperwork completed before arrest attempts can begin - when asked. "Although eventually completed, the delay resulted in no action being taken to locate and arrest Craig Hutsby prior to the rape being committed," it said. PC Joseph Lovelock has a case answer for misconduct for failing to properly complete a form for the victim, the IPCC concluded. "This meant she was not identified as being at high risk of harm and appropriate measures to manage that risk could not be made," it said. Action taken by

original: The cut, which took the markets by surprise, was the first since 2012, and comes into effect on Saturday. The one-year lending rate will also be reduced from 6% to 5.6%. On Thursday figures showed China's factory output contracting for the first time in six months. Economic growth slowed to a five-year low of 7.3% last quarter. Many economists had expected China to stimulate economic growth through fiscal spending rather than lowering rates. To offset the effect of lower rates on savers the bank said it would give banks the flexibility to offer higher deposit rates, up to 1.2 times the benchmark level, rather than 1.1 times. Shares in mining companies jumped by 3-4% after the cut on the hope that better growth would help sales of raw materials to China. Shares in Rio Tinto surged 3.9% percent and BHP Billiton rose 2.9%. The Australian and New Zealand currencies also strengthened reflecting their dependence on trade with China. President Xi Jinping told chief executives at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation Summit
variant_1: The unexpected rate cut, the first since 2012, will take effect on Saturday, with the one-year lending rate dropping from 6% to 5.6%. Recent data showed China's factory output shrinking for the first time in six months, and economic growth slowed to 7.3% last quarter, its lowest in five years. Many economists anticipated China would boost growth via fiscal spending rather than rate cuts. To balance the impact on savers, the bank will allow banks to offer deposit rates up to 1.2 times the benchmark instead of 1.1. Mining stocks rose 3-4% post-cut, fueled by hopes of improved growth boosting raw material sales to China. Rio Tinto shares climbed 3.9%, BHP Billiton 2.9%, while the Australian and New Zealand dollars strengthened due to their trade ties with China. President Xi Jinping addressed chief executives at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation Summit.
variant_2: The rate cut, surprising markets as the first since 2012, is effective Saturday, with the one-year lending rate lowered from 6% to 5.6%. On Thursday, data indicated China's factory output declined for the first time in six months, and growth slowed to a five-year low of 7.3% last quarter. Economists largely expected fiscal measures rather than rate cuts to stimulate growth. To mitigate effects on savers, banks may now offer deposit rates up to 1.2 times the benchmark, raised from 1.1. Following the cut, mining company shares rose 3-4%, anticipating better raw material sales to China, with Rio Tinto up 3.9% and BHP Billiton 2.9%. The Australian and New Zealand currencies also strengthened, reflecting their trade reliance on China. President Xi Jinping spoke to CEOs at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation Summit.

original: The 10 trees have been nominated by members of the public for the competition run by the Woodland Trust charity. A public vote will decide the winner for England's 'Tree of the Year' award. This annual contest, run by the Woodland Trust charity, celebrates and recognizes the importance and beauty of the country's oldest, most varied, and often most overlooked natural monuments. This year’s nominees include a 500-year-old Mulberry tree in Buckinghamshire, a historic Oak in Cornwall, and a rare Elm in Brighton. Each tree carries its unique narrative, making the competition not only a celebration of nature, but also of heritage and history. The public vote aims to raise awareness about the preservation of these natural heritages. The winning tree will represent the nation in the European Tree of the Year contest next year. Voting will remain open until September 24 and the winner will be announced in October. The Woodland Trust encourages everyone to participate in this celebration of nature's magnificent giants.

original: North, 24, landed on his head after a high tackle from Adam Thompstone in his side's 19-11 defeat against Leicester Tigers on Saturday, 3 December. "I read some reports he must finish and stop playing. He doesn't want to be treated like that," Mallinder said. "All George wants to do is get back and play rugby." The Wales international previously had a six-month spell out of the game after suffering a series of blows to the head during matches, including a serious concussion when scoring a try against Wasps in March 2015. Media playback is not supported on this device The former Scarlets winger will sit out Northampton's game against Sale Sharks on Boxing Day because of the incident, despite saying he was not knocked out. "He said he can remember going up in the air, he remembers landing on the floor, he remembers his head striking the floor and he said he wasn't unconscious," Mallinder told BBC Look
variant_1: North, 24, hit his head following a high tackle by Adam Thompstone during his team's 19-11 loss to Leicester Tigers on Saturday, 3 December. "I saw some reports saying he should retire and stop playing. He refuses to be treated that way," Mallinder commented. "George just wants to recover and return to rugby." The Wales international had previously been sidelined for six months after multiple head injuries in games, including a serious concussion when scoring against Wasps in March 2015. The former Scarlets winger will miss Northampton's Boxing Day match against Sale Sharks due to the incident, though he claims he did not lose consciousness. "He said he remembers going up, landing, his head hitting the ground, and that he wasn’t unconscious," Mallinder told BBC Look.

original: Spencer Flower claimed his involvement with a social housing company was not relevant to a debate in 2013 over the future of housing in east Dorset. But he was found guilty of voting illegally as the firm could have benefitted from the plan being passed. The Conservative councillor, 72, will be allowed to remain in public office. Flower, of Verwood, Dorset, was given a six-month conditional discharge and ordered to pay Â£930 costs. A district judge at Bournemouth Magistrates' Court ruled he had broken laws under the Localism Act 2011. Speaking outside court, Flower refused to comment on his political future. He said: "I am surprised and disappointed that the court has found for the prosecution this morning on a technicality. "The decision was a conditional discharge for six months - the lowest possible penalty. "The court emphasised the total lack of any personal gain or intent on my part." Flower, who is also an East Dorset councillor, voted in February 2013 on East Dorset's core strategy while non-executive director of charitable social housing company

original:
Buckingham Palace announced on Friday evening that the Queen would not attend because she had gastroenteritis. Lord Lieutenant of West Glamorgan Byron Lewis, who was supposed to accompany the Queen to the event, expressed his well wishes for her quick recovery. 

Buckingham Palace announced on Friday evening that the Queen would not attend because she had gastroenteritis. The Queen, who had been scheduled to attend a series of engagements in Swansea, Wales, was advised by her doctors to rest. Lord Lieutenant of West Glamorgan, Byron Lewis, who was due to accompany the Queen at the event, empathised with her situation, stating, "Her Majesty's health comes first. We wish her a swift recovery."

Gastroenteritis is an inflammation of the stomach and intestines, usually resulting from bacterial toxins or viral infection and causing vomiting and diarrhea. Palace officials assured the public that the Queen is being well taken care of and is in good spirits despite her illness.

In light of this situation, the palace has not announced any changes to the Queen's schedule for the upcoming week. People across the nation are sending their best wishes to the Queen

original: A report from British Marine, which represents the leisure, superyacht and small commercial marine industry, said superyacht revenues for the year to April 2016 had reached £605m. Revenues for the whole sector rose 1.6% to £3.01bn, the first time the £3bn mark has been breached since 2008-2009. However, the report predicted growth would slow during 2017. It said uncertainty over Brexit negotiations was likely to curb demand. Total revenue fell in the wake of financial crisis, reaching its lowest point in the financial year 2011-2012 of £2,85bn and has been gradually picking up since then. Increased revenue from engine and equipment manufacturing, as well as a jump in sales of hire and charter boats, are believed to have driven the sales increase. Exports for the year were down 0.7% to £882m but British Marine said that in the last few months the industry had benefited from the fall

Monmouth MP David Davies told BBC Wales S4C was a "special case as it promotes the Welsh language". Ministers have said S4C should aim for similar cost savings as the BBC. On Thursday, Labour warned that cuts to the BBC's budget threatened S4C, but Culture Secretary John Whittingdale told MPs there was a commitment to the channel "within the next couple of years", and he hoped to have discussions with its management in the near future. Mr Davies told BBC Radio Cymru's Rhaglen Dylan Jones, on Friday: "The government realise the importance of S4C and that it's more than a station, it's important to the future of the Welsh language." Mr Davies also hinted that the Welsh Affairs Committee, which he chairs, could consider conducting an inquiry into broadcasting, including S4C. "These are personal views but

original:
The Swiss bank said US regulators were investigating potential sales of so called "bearer bonds". These bonds can be transferred without registering ownership, enabling wealthy owners to potentially evade tax obligations. 

The Swiss bank said US regulators were investigating potential sales of so-called "bearer bonds". These bonds can be transferred without registering ownership, enabling wealthy individuals to potentially dodge tax obligations. The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) are reportedly leading the probe, which could hold significant implications for global finance. 

Bearer bonds, which were outlawed in the US in 1982 due to their use in money laundering and tax evasion, are still legal in other countries, including Switzerland. Critics argue that these unregistered securities are a loophole in tax law that primarily benefits the ultra-wealthy. 

The investigation comes amid increased efforts by US authorities to crack down on offshore tax evasion. The Swiss bank, which has not been named, could face severe penalties if found guilty of facilitating tax evasion through the sale of bearer bonds. The bank has not offered any comment on the investigation as of yet.

original:
Their first stop on a busy day of public engagements was a tour of the Giant's Causeway in County Antrim. The Unesco World Heritage Site, The Giant's Causeway, was the first stop on a day filled with public engagements for the duo. Located in County Antrim, the world-renowned site is a geological marvel, celebrated for its distinctive hexagonal basalt columns, formed millions of years ago by volcanic activity. 

During the visit, they engaged with passionate locals and dedicated conservationists to discuss the ongoing preservation efforts and the importance of maintaining this site as a beacon of geological significance. They also learned how this natural wonder continues to play a critical role in the area's tourism industry. 

While there, they were also treated to a display of local cultural heritage, including traditional music and dance performances, providing a vivid example of the rich cultural legacy of County Antrim. 

The visit emphasized their commitment to supporting both the natural and cultural treasures of the regions they visit, showcasing the important balance between conservation and cultural heritage.

They also discovered how this natural marvel continues to be vital to the local tourism sector. The visit highlighted their dedication to supporting both the natural and cultural assets of the regions they explore, demonstrating the crucial balance between conservation and cultural heritage.

original: Matthew Eteson is on trial at Preston Crown Court for the manslaughter by gross negligence of Kelly Webster, 36, and Lauren Thornton. The pair died in their sleep aboard a boat on Windermere in April 2013. Mr Eteson, 42, from Hale in Greater Manchester, denies the charge. The family had gone to the Lake District for the Easter bank holiday weekend to celebrate a friend's birthday. But on the afternoon of 1 April, Mr Eteson removed the generator from the deck and used it to power a 1kW fan heater to heat the sleeping quarter, prosecutor Mr Graham Reeds QC said. The court was told that there had been no warning to the build-up of the toxic gas because the carbon monoxide sensors had previously been disabled. Mr Reeds said the mother and daughter, both from Leyland in Lancashire, were found dead in their sleeping positions aboard the the second-hand Bayliner 285 motor

original: The fragile piece of wood is all that remains of the Nanteos Cup, a wooden chalice named after the mansion in Aberystwyth where it was once kept. Some believe it was the cup from which Christ drank at the Last Supper and that it has healing powers. It was stolen in 2014 before being returned to its owners a year later. It has now been donated to the library in Aberystwyth where thousands of people are expected to view it over the coming months. Pedr ap Llwyd, director of collections and public programmes, said visitors would finally be able to view the "mysterious object". "This is truly a remarkable object and a very interesting addition to the national collections." The cup is claimed to have been brought to Britain by Joseph of Arimathea after the death of Christ and then taken to Nanteos Mansion by seven monks from Strata Florida, Ceredigion, during the reign of Henry Vlll. These beautiful pictures are the first ever taken of a wild lioness nursing a cub from a different species - an extremely rare event. The pair were spotted in the Ngorongoro Conservation Area, Tanzania, by a group of wildlife photographers who couldn't believe their eyes. 

The lioness, dubbed 'Mother Theresa of the Animal Kingdom,' was seen suckling a leopard cub estimated to be just three weeks old. Experts claim it is rare for a lioness to nurse another's offspring, let alone from another species. This rare interspecies interaction has captured the hearts of wildlife enthusiasts across the globe.

Scientists from the WildCRU at Oxford University have suggested that the unusual relationship could be the result of the lioness’ strong maternal instincts. The leopard cub, possibly orphaned or abandoned, has found an unlikely savior. 

As wild predators continue to be threatened by human encroachment, poaching, and climate change, this heartwarming story serves as a poignant reminder of the beauty and

original:
Regina Hungerford, 56, denied striking a 17-year-old as he listened to music in her class at Merthyr Tydfil College. The veteran teacher, who is highly respected among colleagues, stands accused of misconduct during a vocational training session. She allegedly smacked the teenager on the back of his head when he refused to remove his headphones and pay attention to the ongoing lesson.

Hungerford, however, fervently contests the accusation, insisting that she only "tapped" the student in a bid to grab his attention. According to her testimony, she used no force and certainly no intent to harm the student. 

The police were informed about the incident following a report from the college. After a thorough investigation, they concluded that there was insufficient evidence to pursue a criminal prosecution. The case has now moved to the hands of the Education Workforce Council, which will ultimately decide the fate of Hungerford's teaching career. 

The incident has sparked a lively local debate on teacher

original: The hashtag #penuriecarburantdansunfilm, which translates as "fuel shortage in a film", became France's top Twitter trend on Tuesday, with more than 5,000 tweets. A strike over new labour laws is now affecting all of France's eight oil refineries. An estimated 20% of petrol stations have either run dry or are low on supplies. In their posts, French social media users talk about films such as Total Recall, the title of both a 1990 and 2012 science fiction film. Total is also the name of a French multinational oil and gas company. Some users also changed film titles to reflect the shortage: Pulp Fiction was renamed Pump Friction, The Full Monty became The Fuel Monty and Mad Max: Fury Bicycle Lane replaced Mad Max: Fury Road. American actor Vin Diesel's surname and his Hollywood blockbusters attracted particular attention, with people inventing several titles for his Fast and Furious series: Last and Furious, Pas Fast Mais Furious (translation: Not Fast But Furious),

French social media users referenced films like Total Recall, a sci-fi movie from both 1990 and 2012. Total is also the name of a major French oil company. Some users humorously altered film titles to highlight the shortage: Pulp Fiction became Pump Friction, The Full Monty was changed to The Fuel Monty, and Mad Max: Fury Road turned into Mad Max: Fury Bicycle Lane. Vin Diesel's surname and his Hollywood hits drew special attention, inspiring creative titles for his Fast and Furious movies such as Last and Furious and Pas Fast Mais Furious (meaning Not Fast But Furious).

original: The care at Stafford Hospital left some patients drinking water from vases, it is claimed, and receptionists assessing emergency cases. Julie Bailey, who founded the Cure the NHS group after the death of her mother at the hospital in 2007, said that the levels of neglect were horrifying. She related stories of starving patients forced to eat from bins, and of those left in agony as overworked nurses failed to administer medication. Perhaps most concerning was the revelation that unqualified receptionists were often left to evaluate patients in emergency cases. A report into the scandal, published in 2013, found that between 400 and 1,200 patients may have died unnecessarily due to subpar care. The damning evidence has led to a national conversation about healthcare standards in the UK, and about the systemic failings that can lead to such a disaster. Bailey continues to fight for justice and reform, insisting that nothing short of a complete overhaul of the system will prevent the same issues from recurring in the future.

original: Erika Murray, 31, was arrested on Thursday night after a neighbour alerted police over the safety of other children living at the house. Detectives found the bodies in what they described as a squalid, vermin-infested home. On Friday Ms Murray pleaded not guilty to all charges. Those include foetal death concealment, witness intimidation and permitting substantial injury to a child. Her lawyer said he believed she suffered with mental illness. "You want answers in circumstances like this... mental illness doesn't always provide those kinds of answers," Ms Murray's lawyer Keith Halpern said after her court appearance. Police were first called to the home in Blackstone when a neighbour was approached by one of the children living there, said Tim Connolly, a spokesman for the Worcester district attorney. The ten-year boy is reported to have asked the neighbour, "How do you get a baby to stop crying?" The neighbour went with the boy and found the crying
variant_1: Erika Murray, 31, was taken into custody Thursday night after a neighbor alerted authorities about the safety concerns for other children living in the house. Detectives discovered the bodies in what they described as a filthy, vermin-infested residence. On Friday, Murray pleaded not guilty to all charges, including concealment of foetal death, witness intimidation, and allowing serious harm to a child. Her attorney stated he believed she had a mental illness. "In cases like this, you seek answers... but mental illness doesn't always explain everything," said her lawyer Keith Halpern after the court hearing. Police were initially called to the Blackstone home when a neighbor was approached by one of the children there, according to Tim Connolly, a spokesman for the Worcester district attorney. The ten-year-old boy reportedly asked the neighbor, "How do you get a baby to stop crying?" The neighbor followed the boy and found the crying.

original: Heading the processions were some of those caught up in the suicide bomb attacks on Belgium's airport and metro station that killed 32 people. Belgian broadcaster described the march as "calm and silent". The march had been due to be held a week after the 22 March attacks, but officials asked for it to be postponed because of the security threat. Relatives of victims, and paramedics and airport staff affected by the attacks joined people of several religious faiths on Sunday's march. Flowers were carried in memory of those who lost their lives. The procession took them past the Molenbeek neighbourhood - where many of those alleged to have carried out the attacks in both Brussels and Paris had lived - and to the makeshift memorial outside the city's stock exchange. One of the organisers of the march, Hassan Bousetta, told the AFP news agency: "When our fellow citizens, defenceless civilians, are cut down in a cowardly attack, all citizens should stand up to express their disgust and solidarity." The turnout was less than half of the 15,000 organisers had hoped for. The attacks

Flowers were carried in remembrance of those who died. The procession passed through the Molenbeek neighborhood, where many alleged attackers from Brussels and Paris had lived, and ended at the temporary memorial outside the city’s stock exchange. Hassan Bousetta, one of the march organizers, told AFP: "When innocent citizens fall victim to a cowardly attack, everyone should unite to show their condemnation and solidarity." The turnout was less than half of the 15,000 expected by organizers. The attacks

original:
New shots of Charlene Downes, 14, who was last seen in Blackpool town centre, were discovered during a trawl of CCTV. The images surfaced nearly two decades after the teenager went missing, reigniting hope in the ongoing investigation. 

Downes vanished without a trace on November 1, 2003, sparking one of the most extensive missing person cases in the history of Lancashire Police. Despite numerous appeals, her whereabouts remained a mystery. The newly discovered CCTV footage shows Charlene walking towards the Coral Island complex at around 3:35 pm on the day she disappeared. 

The discovery has provided a significant breakthrough in the cold case. Lancashire Police stated, "This could potentially lead to new information that is crucial for our investigation." The police are now appealing for anyone who was in the vicinity of Coral Island on the day Charlene disappeared to come forward. The family continues to live in hope that they will one day find closure in this heart-wrenching case.

original:
England have been hit by injuries in the back row, with James Haskell, Sam Jones and Mike Williams all ruled out, along with the versatile Tom Wood. This has left coach Eddie Jones scrambling for options before their Six Nations championship clash against Scotland. 

The RFU confirmed on Monday that Haskell, Jones, Williams, and Wood have all picked up injuries during training. Haskell and Williams suffered foot injuries, Sam Jones sustained a fractured leg, while Wood is nursing a shoulder injury. 

The injury crisis is a huge blow for England, who have been enjoying a solid run in the Six Nations Championship. This comes as an unexpected disruption to their preparation, which had been focused on maintaining their unbeaten run in the championship. 

Despite the setback, Coach Eddie Jones seemed optimistic. "We have depth in the squad, which will allow other players to step up," he said. 

But with a strong Scottish side lying in wait, the four absentees will undoubtedly be a significant loss. Only time will tell if England can maintain their winning momentum without their key back row players.

original: Kevin Mcleod's body was found in Wick harbour in February 1997. The 24-year-old's death was treated as accidental, but his family believe that injuries on his body showed that he was murdered. An assessment was done of "all information known" regarding the death after contact between his family and chief constable Phil Gormley. Police said the review had included tracing and speaking to people who were in Wick the night Mr Mcleod died, but who had not previously come forward. Mr Mcleod's mother, June, told BBC Scotland last month that if the assessment "turned up nothing new" she and her family would continue to fight for a fresh investigation. original:
The bodies of backpackers Miss Witheridge, 23, from Norfolk, and Mr Miller, 24, from Jersey, were found on a beach in the popular tourist destination, the Koh Tao island in Thailand. The pair, who were traveling separately, met at a local hotel where they were staying.

The local authorities discovered their bodies early Monday morning, following a beach party the previous night. Both had suffered severe head injuries and, according to initial police reports, appeared to be victims of a savage attack.

Their deaths have sent shockwaves through the international backpacking community, leading to an outpouring of condolences and calls for increased safety measures for young travelers in foreign countries. The British embassy in Bangkok is providing support to the grieving families and working closely with Thai police to expedite the ongoing investigation.

The tragic incident has also triggered a significant decline in tourism to Koh Tao, known as a paradise for divers, reflecting the growing concerns over the safety of tourists in the region.

original:
Research for the College of Policing suggested that officers were focusing on cases involving violence and overlooking other risk factors. Three unnamed police forces in England and Wales have been identified in a recent research study conducted by the College of Policing. The findings suggest that officers were primarily focusing on cases involving violence and overlooking other significant risk factors. This bias towards violent offences may be compromising the efficacy of policing in these areas, potentially leaving citizens vulnerable to other types of crime.

The research highlighted the need for deeper insights and broader scopes in threat assessments to ensure comprehensive law enforcement. The three unnamed police forces have reportedly taken the findings on board and are now reassessing their approaches to address this issue.

The findings also urge for improved training and resource allocation, particularly for areas of crime that may not involve violence but are equally detrimental, such as cybercrime, fraud, and drug offenses. The College of Policing hopes that this research can provide an impetus for change, not just within the three forces investigated, but across all forces, improving the overall standard of public safety.

The study emphasized the necessity for more comprehensive threat assessments and broader perspectives in law enforcement. In response, the three unnamed forces are revising their strategies to incorporate these insights. Additionally, the findings call for enhanced training and better allocation of resources toward non-violent crimes like cybercrime, fraud, and drug offenses. Sterling rose 1.86% against the dollar to $1.32.40, and was 1.73% higher against the euro, marking its strongest performance in over a year. This surge has been attributed to a combination of factors, including continued post-Brexit optimism and stronger than anticipated economic data.

Analysts attribute the bullish sentiment around the sterling to the recent release of robust UK employment figures, which revealed a surprising resilience in the job market despite pandemic-related challenges. The currency's upturn also reflects the positive initial impact of Brexit, with traders anticipating a prosperous future for the UK outside of the European Union.

Furthermore, the Bank of England's decision to hold interest rates steady has contributed to the pound's rise. The central bank's statement that it sees no immediate need for negative rates has reassured investors, boosting confidence in the sterling.

On 30 January 1915, England played Scotland in a charity match organised by former England international and Northampton Saints captain Edgar Mobbs. The aim of the match was to raise funds for soldiers affected by the ongoing World War I. This first-of-its-kind event demonstrated the power of sports to unite nations and foster patriotic spirit even in the darkest of times.

During the match, Mobbs' leadership was instrumental in carving a thrilling victory for England and the event marked a significant chapter in the annals of Rugby history. His team displayed exceptional skill, courage, and solidarity – qualities that mirrored those of the soldiers they were playing in honor of.

The charity match was a resounding success, raising substantial funds that were directly channelled towards offering financial aid to the brave soldiers on the frontlines. This game didn't just signify a victory on the rugby field, but also a triumph of human spirit and generosity.

original: The news agency's account was suspended and it advised all tweets should be ignored until further notice. The false message said: "Breaking: Two Explosions in the White House and Barack Obama is injured." US markets were spooked by the tweet; the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 150 points as it was retweeted. On Tuesday evening, the FBI said it was investigating the incident. White House spokesman Jay Carney told reporters soon after the tweet was published that President Obama was fine, and financial markets quickly recovered the lost ground. AP said later: "The @AP twitter account has been hacked. The tweet about an attack at the White House is false." The account was back online on Wednesday. The agency said the attack came after repeated attempts by hackers to steal the passwords of AP journalists, adding that it was working to correct the issue. original: Charles Blackman's oil work Women Lovers features two nude women resting on a bed beside a cat. Art broker Mossgreen tried to promote it on Facebook, but the social media network rejected it for "advertising adult products or services". Mossgreen chief executive Paul Summer said the decision was "ridiculous". "This is a very beautiful image that is not overtly sexual in any shape or form," he told the BBC. "It's like going back to the 1950s. It's ridiculous to censor this sort of thing." Facebook said its decision was final, although Mossgreen has since reposted images of the work. "Such ads lead to negative user sentiment and we have zero tolerance towards such advertisements," Facebook said in a message. Last month, a French teacher took Facebook to court after it suspended his account for posting an image of a nude woman painted by 19th Century artist Gustave Courbet. Mr Summer said Women Lovers was expected to sell for more than A$45,000

Hanjin filed for receivership in South Korea last week after attempts to bail out the indebted company failed. Ports have refused to accept Hanjin ships, leaving cargo stranded and causing chaos in global trade. 

Hanjin filed for receivership in South Korea last week after attempts to bail out the indebted company failed. Ports worldwide, from Shanghai to New York, have refused to accept Hanjin's cargo ships due to uncertainty over who would pay docking fees, container storage, and unloading bills. This has led to an unprecedented logjam in the global supply chain.

Hundreds of thousands of containers carrying more than $14 billion worth of goods are stranded at sea, affecting retailers and manufacturers worldwide. The impact is especially severe as preparations for the holiday season are underway, causing considerable disruption and potential losses. 

The collapse of Hanjin, the world's seventh-largest container shipper, has sent shockwaves through the global shipping industry, which is already grappling with low freight rates due to an excess of ships and slowing global trade. The South Korean government's decision not to rescue Hanjin has raised questions about the future of other struggling shippers, potentially triggering

The company behind the abattoir in Haverfordwest, Emcol 2008 Ltd, collapsed in January 2016 with debts of £660,000, leaving local farmers and suppliers in a precarious situation. The firm's sudden closure sent shockwaves through the local economy as it was one of the major employers in the area.

The company's financial woes were traced to a range of factors, including a decline in demand, rising operational costs and increased competition from overseas meat suppliers. The inability to secure sufficient funds for necessary modernization and expansion efforts further exacerbated the situation. 

A significant number of jobs losses were reported, adding to the economic hardship faced by the region. The liquidation process left many local farmers and suppliers unpaid, furthering destabilizing the local agricultural economy.

The fragile piece of wood is all that remains of the Nanteos Cup, a wooden chalice named after the mansion in Aberystwyth, Wales, where it was preserved. The cup, believed to have been made in the 14th century, has been at the center of many a legend, with some even claiming it to be the Holy Grail itself, the cup used by Jesus at the Last Supper.

In recent years, the Nanteos Cup has suffered extensive damage, reducing it to a small fragment. Despite its diminished state, the relic continues to be revered, with believers attributing healing powers to it. Kelly, an unemployed man with a history of mental health issues, was reportedly under the influence of alcohol when he attacked Beattie in a heated argument that spiraled out of control.

Police were called to Beattie's home in the early hours of the morning on October 22, following a distress call that reported a violent disturbance. On arriving at the scene, they were met with a chilling sight - Beattie was found lifeless, with clear signs of strangulation.

Kelly was arrested at the scene and later charged with homicide. He has pleaded not guilty, citing self-defence, a claim that local authorities and prosecutors are currently investigating.

original:
The doctors' union had refused to sit down and talk about improving patient care and had spread "misinformation", he told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show.

The doctors' union had refused to sit down and talk about improving patient care and had spread "misinformation", he told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show. The union's recent actions have sparked a heated debate about the future of healthcare in the United Kingdom, raising questions about the role of medical professionals in shaping health policies.

According to critics, the refusal by the union to engage in constructive dialogue is hindering efforts to streamline processes, enhance patient satisfaction, and ultimately improve health outcomes. They argue that the union's stance is primarily driven by self-interest, rather than the welfare of patients.

The union, however, has denied these allegations, maintaining that their primary concern is the welfare of both patients and doctors. They argue that they are being unfairly targeted and scapegoated for larger systemic issues within the NHS.

original:
The party's 54 sitting MPs are expected to be endorsed as candidates. A decision will also be made about the fate of Natalie McGarry and Michelle Thomson, both under investigation.

The party's 54 sitting MPs are expected to be endorsed as candidates for the upcoming general elections in a move that is being seen as a strategic decision to maintain stability and continuity within the party. This endorsement is expected to boost party morale and also bolster the chances of the party securing its hold in the constituencies they currently represent.

A decision will also be made about the fate of Natalie McGarry and Michelle Thomson, both of whom are under scrutiny for alleged financial discrepancies. The two MPs have been at the center of a controversy that has cast a shadow on the integrity of the party. The decision on their candidacy will be a crucial one as it would signal the party's stand on issues of financial impropriety.

Party insiders are hopeful that the decision will be in favor of the party's reputation and public trust. The upcoming elections will be pivotal in testing the party's resilience amidst these challenges.

original: Hundreds of people were evacuated from their homes and businesses were shut when major flooding hit Stoke Newington, Blackheath and Islington. Sadiq Khan said people were "rightly furious it appears lessons are not being learnt". Thames Water has said a "full investigation" will take place "to reduce the risk of further disruption". Mr Khan said the "huge damage" caused was "a devastating thing to happen in the run-up to Christmas". "It is right that Thames Water have launched a full investigation, and residents and business must now get full compensation," he said. Director Bob Collington told the BBC the firm had spent "about Â£1bn a year upgrading our network" but "clearly the events of the last few weeks point to the fact that we need to do even more". Some business owners have accused the company of "incompetence" over the floods. Gonen Ozer, who owns two businesses in Stoke Newington, said the mains had been leaking for several days but the water firm had only "patched it up temporarily". "I can only describe Thames Water's attitude as reckless, irresponsible and totally unprofessional", he said. Emily Oliphant was in her Blackheath

original:
Matthew Eteson is on trial at Preston Crown Court for the manslaughter by gross negligence of Kelly Webster, 36, and her ten-year-old daughter, Lauren Thornton. The pair were found dead on a boat owned by Eteson, moored on Lake Windermere in April 2013. It's alleged that their untimely deaths were the result of carbon monoxide poisoning, resulting from a faulty generator Eteson had reportedly installed on the boat.

The prosecution states that Eteson, a gas fitter by trade, had a duty of care towards his partner and her daughter and failed to meet it. They argue that it was his negligence in failing to ensure that the generator was safe that led directly to the tragic deaths. 

Eteson denies the charges, his defense team plans to argue that the deaths were a tragic accident. The trial is expected to last for several weeks, with the outcome having potential legal implications for boat owners nationwide.

original:
Spencer Flower claimed his involvement with a social housing company was not relevant to a debate in 2013 over the future of housing in east Dorset. He defended his actions amid allegations of a conflict of interest. Flower, a member of the Dorset County Council, found himself at the center of controversy when it was revealed that he held a significant stake in a housing company involved in projects in the area.

Critics argued that Flower's affiliation with the company created a conflict between his private interests and his public duties. But Flower insisted that his business interests did not affect his participation in the debate and decision-making process. He stated that he had always been transparent about his business affiliations and had refrained from participating in matters where there might be a conflict.

This incident has ignited a conversation about the need for stricter rules around the disclosure of council members' business interests. It has also raised questions about how local government decisions are made and the extent to which personal interests may influence these decisions.

original:
PC Frances Tilley admitted she had "destroyed her career" after evading payment for a journey between Bristol Temple Meads station and Castle Cary. The incident, which took place last year, has come to light this week after a disciplinary hearing found her guilty of gross misconduct.

Tilley, a police officer with over ten years of service, confessed to travelling without a valid ticket and subsequently providing false information during the formal investigation. This incident has resulted in her dismissal from the Avon and Somerset Police Department.

The panel, chaired by independent legal adviser, Jane Jones, concluded that Tilley's actions were deliberate and constituted a serious breach of the Standards of Professional Behaviour. The decision to dismiss her was unanimous, reflecting the severity of her misconduct. 

In a statement, Tilley expressed remorse for her actions and acknowledged the self-inflicted end of her career. The incident serves as a crucial reminder that police officers, like all individuals, are expected to uphold the law at all times.

original: Regina Hungerford, 56, denied striking a 17-year-old as he listened to music in her class at Merthyr Tydfil College. But a disciplinary panel ruled contact with the pupil was probably made and her conduct had been "unacceptable". On Thursday, the Education Workforce Council imposed the suspension, saying: "The public interest is in favour of her being able to teach again." Mrs Hungerford admitted shouting and slamming a book on the desk of the "provocative and disruptive" teenager as he listened to rap music in her classroom - but always denied hitting his head. She was cleared, on appeal, of a criminal charge for assaulting the pupil during a maths lesson for those with learning difficulties. But in November, a disciplinary panel found, on the balance of probabilities, she had made physical conduct with the pupil on the head or hand. The panel found she had "acted in an inappropriate way" and ruled it was professional misconduct. During the hearing,

original: Mrs Foster said on Wednesday that she wanted to better understand those who love the language. She said she wanted to "listen to and engage with those from the Gaelic Irish background, those without the party political background". Mr Ó Muilleoir said he hoped the meeting would happen soon. "It's a positive move," he said. "Anything that encourages dialogue, that encourages conversations, that encourages increased understanding has to be positive." Stormont's parties have "paused" talks to strike a deal to form an executive until after Easter. The parties have yet to find a deal almost six weeks after the assembly election. One of Sinn Féin's key priorities in the talks is a guarantee that an Irish Language Act will be enacted. In February, Arlene Foster said the DUP would never agree to an Irish Language Act. But she has now said she would meet with "people who genuinely love the Irish language and don't want to use it as a political weapon".
